message: Happy New Year, Alaska! Here’s to a happy, healthy, and prosperous 2017.  My personal New Year's resolution is to focus on health: getting to bed earlier, eating healthier, and working out. It's going to be a wonderful year!

Today I was sworn in to my fourth term as U.S. Senator for Alaska. It is an incredibly humbling experience to be in this position and one that I do not take lightly. I thank everyone for their support, and I look forward to continuing to stand with and represent all Alaskans.
Happy Statehood Birthday Alaska! On this day in 1959, Alaska became the 49th state admitted to the union.

Today I had the opportunity to meet with Betsy DeVos, the Secretary of Education nominee. We discussed many important education issues facing Alaska and the nation, and I look forward to continuing the conversation next week during her confirmation hearing in the Senate HELP Committee.

For nearly 40 years, Alaskans have proven that we can responsibly develop our natural resources while protecting the environment. I’m proud to have introduced today, alongside my colleague Senator Dan Sullivan, S. 49, the Alaska Oil and Gas Production Act, legislation that would allow limited oil and natural gas development within the non-wilderness portion of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (ANWR). Alaskans overwhelmingly support responsible development in the non-wilderness portion of ANWR and there is no valid reason why we should not be allowed to proceed. Allowing development would create new jobs, reduce our deficits, and protect our national security and competitiveness for a generation.

President Obama’s unilateral withdrawals have routinely come with complete disregard for Alaskans’ concerns and opposition, threatening energy, mining, fishing, recreation, and other reasonable uses of public land and waters. This is why 25 of my fellow Senators joined me to introduce a bill to facilitate greater local input and require state approval before national monuments can be designated on federal lands and waters. At this point, we have no choice but to reform the Antiquities Act to ensure that the people being impacted by these designations are heard and respected.

Yesterday I had a good, productive meeting with Rep. Ryan Zinke, a former Navy SEAL who is now the President-elect’s nominee for Interior Secretary. He has been tapped to lead the Department that includes agencies such as the Bureau of Land Management, Fish and Wildlife Service, National Park Service, U.S. Geological Survey, Bureau of Indian Affairs, and Indian Health Service – all with a huge impact and presence in Alaska – so we had many issues to discuss. We had a great conversation, and as the Chairman of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, I look forward to advancing his nomination quickly.
Happy 98th birthday to WWII hero, legendary bush pilot, and all-around great Alaskan Urban Rahoi!

I am sorry to hear of the passing of former Fairbanks Fire Chief Cummings, who recently lost his long battle with cancer. I send my condolences and prayers -  to the Cummings family and the Fairbanks community. I had the privilege of working with Chief Cummings on a number of projects aimed to benefit the city of Fairbanks. While Chief Cummings was known for being a man of few words, his integrity and commitment to Fairbanks and the Fire Department spoke volumes. He was a tireless advocate for the city’s fire department. I will be thinking of Fairbanks - as you all mourn and celebrate the life of this great man.
Thanks to the U.S. Coast Guard for a safe rescue of the crew of the fishing vessel Lady Gudny. And thanks for your continued efforts to keep mariners safe and protect U.S. waters.

On Friday, I met with former Governor Rick Perry who is the President-elect’s nominee for Energy Secretary. He will  be at the helm of a major federal department that makes significant decisions on U.S. energy policy. He and I had a good discussion about energy issues that matter to Alaska and the nation and, as chairman of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, I look forward to continuing the conversation at the upcoming nominations hearing.

Congratulations to Vertical Harvest Hydroponics of Alaska for winning the American Farm Bureau’s Rural Entrepreneurship Challenge! Vertical Harvest Hydroponics is overcoming rural Alaska’s unique food security challenges by applying new, innovative technologies to meet our nutritional needs in the last frontier. VHH grows vegetables 365 days a year in insulated shipping containers built specifically for remote arctic conditions, allowing rural Alaskans to access healthy, fresh produce grown in their community. It makes me proud to see Alaska’s companies recognized on the national stage.

I remain committed to repealing the Affordable Care Act, and I am equally committed to ensuring that all Alaskans have access to affordable, quality healthcare. With a new administration and a new Congress we have an opportunity to fulfill both of those commitments, but repeal and replace need to coincide – that’s simply common sense. That is why I’m proud to sign onto an amendment to give the committee process time to work, to allow stakeholders to share their solutions with us, and to ensure that our replacement legislation provides Americans with certainty, access, and truly affordable options for their healthcare needs.
I spoke on CNBC, alongside my colleague Senator Bill Cassidy, about how we are working to create a responsible path forward to repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act.

I’m proud to introduce, along with my colleague Senator Dan Sullivan, legislation to authorize a short, one-lane, gravel, non-commercial road for the isolated community of King Cove to have reliable access to medical transportation. A life-saving road remains the best and only real option to help the people of King Cove. The Aleut people who live in this region care deeply for their lands, but are forced to live in fear that they will not be able to receive proper medical care. After years of secretarial apathy, I am eager to work with a new administration and a new Interior Secretary to restore common sense, resolve this horrible injustice, and end their needless pain and suffering.

Today Congressman Don Young, Senator Dan Sullivan and I  introduced legislation to accelerate an equal value land exchange between the Alaska Mental Health Trust and the U.S. Forest Service. The legislation, which nearly passed last Congress, protects important community viewsheds, local trails, and other conservation values while expediting much-needed timber for local operators and generating new revenues for mental health services across the state. Our bill protects lands that are worth protecting, provides critical timber to keep our sawmills running, and raises money for mental health programs in the midst of our state’s ongoing fiscal crisis.

Today, ConocoPhilllips Alaska announced a new oil discovery in the Greater Mooses Tooth located in the northeast portion of the NPR-A. This is good news for Alaskans as this discovery could bring more jobs and investments to Alaska, help keep TAPS filled, and mitigate the State’s budget crisis.

Saddened to hear of the passing of Dale Tran. My condolences and prayers go out to his family and loved ones. I will remember him for his contagious smile and love for helping his community. He will be missed.
First chair at Alyeska this morning with my nephews. Fresh snow! #Alaska
Today we celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s indisputable contribution to our nation. We reflect on the life and legacy of Dr. King; his steadfastness, sacrifices, and commitment to peace.

As always, I enjoyed speaking with Alaskan teachers from across the state at the NEA-Alaska Delegate Assembly in Anchorage this past weekend. I shared the work that lies ahead, both in Alaska and in Washington, D.C., and how I will continue to stand up for Alaska's right to determine what a successful school looks like, how to help struggling schools, and how to meet local needs. And as our state works to fully implement the Every Student Succeeds Act, with its return of local control over our children's education future, I am grateful that Alaska’s teachers are so committed to ensuring every child’s success.
It's moving day here in my DC office. My scheduler Kristen and I are last out of the office tonight. I'm gonna miss Hart 709.

Yesterday I chaired the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee confirmation hearing for Rep. Ryan Zinke to be the next Secretary of the Interior. I highlighted the many energy, resource, and lands issues important to Alaskans and stressed the importance of a collaborative partnership with the federal government and local communities – something we did not see with the Obama administration. I’m pleased Zinke committed to review all the restrictions on Alaskans' use of our lands and waters to determine if they can be reversed. We have a great opportunity to work with the new administration to improve access for hunting, fishing, recreation, responsible development and other purposes. I'm looking forward to it.
So many young Alaskans in D.C. this weekend for the inauguration! It was great catching up with them along with Senator Sullivan and Congressman Young.

Today was a historic day in Washington, D.C. People have been viewing 2017 and this new incoming administration as one of change. Change can be unsettling, but also an extraordinary opportunity for us. I think we need to embrace the opportunities that will present themselves with this new leadership. It's an opportunity for a new exchange of ideas, and my hope is that it will be a peaceful and harmonious exchange. The amazing thing about this country is we have been able to peacefully transition power in a democracy that allows us to continue to be recognized as the strongest, most prosperous and most peaceful nation in the world.
Early this morning we moved the 10-foot Tlingit totem pole from my old office to the new one. The move is now officially complete!

Last Friday the Senate voted to confirm General James Mattis to be Secretary of Defense, the first of President Trump’s cabinet nominees to be confirmed by the Senate. Every indication suggests that General Mattis will make an outstanding Secretary of Defense, given his leadership style and knowledge about the issues and challenges facing our national security. I look forward to working with him to advance our Alaska’s role as a strategic military location.

A huge congratulations to Pete Kaiser for winning the Kuskokwim 300 sled dog race for the 3rd consecutive year! Talk about Alaska tough – this year’s mushers traveled through temperatures with a windchill of 40 below. A true accomplishment for everyone on the trail!

Congratulations to Mountain View for the re-dedication of the improved Mountain View Elementary School! It is a true pleasure to see Alaskan communities come together to provide our children with the resources they need to succeed. Last week’s re-dedication ceremony was a wonderful way to highlight the bright future that the children of Mountain View – the most ethnically diverse community in the nation – will build at their new school.

My Alaska and D.C. offices have been overwhelmed with phone calls from the Lower 48 and the volume of calls has made it difficult for Alaskans to get through in order to express their opinions on many issues including President Trump’s cabinet nominees and the ACA repeal process. Please know that my staff is doing the best they can to manage these phone calls, including listening to voicemail, and we are actively looking for solutions to manage the high volume of calls. I encourage concerned Alaskans to contact my office through my website, if you are having issues getting through on the phone.

The Senate recently confirmed with bipartisan support the nominees for Secretary of Defense, Secretary of Homeland Security, and Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) Director. It is a critical responsibility of the Senate to ensure that those who are working to protect our nation are moved through the confirmation process. I look forward to working with each of these highly qualified individuals to leverage Alaska’s strategic and national security interests for our country.

I am proud to have been named as Chairman of the Interior and Environment Appropriations Subcommittee for this new Congress, a position I have held since 2015. As Chairman I have the ability to question the directors of federal agencies on their budget priorities, and I am able influence how these agencies operate – whether that’s blocking excessive regulations or directing federal resources to where they are needed. I will continue to be a tireless advocate for our state and look forward to providing greater opportunities for Alaskans to build the economy and create healthy communities.

I’m disappointed that the new administration reinstated the Mexico City Policy, which I believe unfairly discriminates against international public health organizations that counsel women about their reproductive health options. I have consistently opposed the Mexico City Policy in previous Senate votes and recently joined with a bipartisan group of colleagues to prohibit its implementation. This legislation ensures that men and women across the globe continue to receive access to vital public health services by allowing public health organizations to continue receiving foreign aid from the U.S. It’s important to note that U.S. funds cannot be used perform abortions. These health clinics are many times the only option for men and women to receive basic, and vital, healthcare services. By providing consistent family planning and reproductive health services in developing countries, we can reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies and improve the health of millions of women and children.

I would like to thank Admiral Papp for his tireless work raising awareness on Arctic issues as the State Department’s Special Representative to the Arctic. The Arctic must be a national and international priority, and it is crucial that we actively address the challenges and opportunities facing the Arctic, while keeping in mind those who live and work and raise their families there. Moving forward, I am dedicated to ensuring the new administration understands our priorities and visions for the Arctic and the people who live in the region.

Thank you to the generous Alaskans across the state who volunteered their time and expertise to help out with Project Homeless Connect – a one stop shop that offered services to individuals and families who are experiencing homelessness.   More info on the event here: http://bit.ly/2juElB4.

Today is International Holocaust Remembrance Day, commemorating the 72nd anniversary of the liberation of the Nazi German Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp in Poland. This is a day where we remember the victims, survivors, and heroes of the Holocaust, ensuring that their stories never be forgotten. The depravity and terror unleashed by the Nazi Regime has forever left a wound on humanity that will never fully go away, yet we work on healing this wound every day by educating others on what happened, ensuring that the atrocities never occur again. We will never forget the men, women and children whose lives ended too soon, as we remember how they lived, and how they died.    Amidst the horror and destruction that was the Holocaust, stories of hope and the perseverance of the human spirit appeared through the clouds of despair. It is crucial that we not only remember the lives of those we lost and those who suffered, but also the heroes who emerged from the darkness to try to make the world a little bit better. As Miep Gies, the heroine who hid Anne Frank, her family, and other Jews during the Holocaust once elegantly stated, “Even an ordinary secretary or a teenager can, within their own small ways, turn on a small light in a dark room."  We are forever thankful to those risked their lives in the face of evil to save the lives of the innocent.
Thanks to the brave Alaskans who plunged into the freezing waters of Resurrection Bay to support the American Cancer Society’s great work! Nearly $100K was raised to help find a cure to cancer.

All weekend long my staff and I have been monitoring implementation of President Trump’s recent Executive Order related to immigration – consulting with both the Department of Homeland Security and stakeholders in Alaska. Like others, we are trying to understand the ramifications of this action, including the suspension of the refugee resettlement program and its impact on Alaskans and those coming to our community. We have spoken with Catholic Social Services of Alaska about the effect of the executive order in our state.   President Trump has made it clear that the security of Americans is his top priority. I agree. I also believe U.S. immigration policy must strike a balance between national security and our values as Americans and that how we implement policy matters. I will be pressing the Administration to address the needs of those impacted by the implementation of this order while we work on the broader policy.

Today I voted to move Betsy DeVos out of the HELP Committee because I have long held the belief that a President has the right to name their Cabinet and that the full Senate should have the opportunity to vote on those nominees. However, it is important to realize that this was NOT the final confirmation vote for DeVos. At this morning’s hearing I said that when it comes to her final confirmation, don’t count on my vote.

I am pleased with President Trump’s nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court, and I look forward to meeting with him and discussing issues of importance to Alaskans. With Judge Gorsuch, western states like Alaska get an individual who understands our lives and lifestyles. He is respected by legal scholars across ideological boundaries and is an originalist and textualist in the model of Justice Scalia. There is no quarrel about his extraordinary intellect, his compelling style of writing, and his commitment to justice. I particularly support Gorsuch in his belief that we must reconsider the Chevron doctrine, which provides that when a regulation is challenged in court, the court must defer to the agency’s interpretation of its own regulation. We share the same belief that the scales should not be tilted in favor of federal agencies when citizens challenge regulations. Those challenging federal actions deserve a level playing field, and I believe they will get that with Judge Gorsuch on the Supreme Court. I give credit to President Trump on this strong nominee.

I am so proud to nominate 34 talented young Alaskans for consideration by the U.S. military academies. These young men and women are some of the best and brightest representing the state of Alaska, and I know these exemplary young candidates will represent our great state with dignity and civility. Their willingness to dedicate themselves to our nation at such a young age should be an inspiration to us all, and I wish them all the very best with their future endeavors.  For a full list of nominees, click below.

After careful consideration, and hearing from thousands of Alaskans, I will vote against Betsy DeVos on final passage for Secretary of Education. I have serious concerns about a nominee to be Secretary of Education who has been so involved in one side of the equation – so immersed in the push for vouchers – that she may be unaware of what actually is successful in the public schools, and what is broken or how to fix them.  Click here for text of my floor speech: http://bit.ly/2jEsYDv

Alaskans are all too aware that our health insurance market is struggling. Last year we dropped to only one provider on our exchange while premium rates have continued to rise. Yesterday I attended a hearing on stabilizing the individual insurance market place, where I pointed out that we must move away from the Affordable Care Act’s “one-size-fits-all” model and begin to give states like Alaska the flexibility they need.

It was great to meet with Sebastian Ashley today, a young AmeriCorps volunteer who has spent time serving in Palmer and hopes to soon return to Alaska for college. I was so impressed by Sebastian’s commitment to bettering communities, especially in rural Alaska.

Judge Neil Gorsuch is a fantastic choice for the Supreme Court of the United States -- an individual with a truly impressive background who has committed himself to the law in a remarkable way. When he was before the Senate for confirmation moving up to the 10th Circuit, he enjoyed very strong support for good reason, as he is a well-qualified jurist with the right view of the role of the court under our Constitution. I look forward to learning more about Judge Gorsuch and to moving forward with the vetting process for his nomination.

Today is National Wear Red Day to promote women’s heart health. Many don’t realize that cardiovascular disease is the number one killer of woman in the United States, and kills more women than every type of cancer combined. I am proud have introduced bipartisan legislation with Senator Mazie Hirono of Hawaii to promote education and awareness regarding the causes, risks, prevention, and treatment of heart disease. The resolution calls special attention to the impacts of cardiovascular disease on minority women and calls particular attention to the serious health risks it presents among Alaska Native and indigenous populations. We must do all we can to enable our women, families, and healthcare providers with the tools and know-how to confront heart disease head on.

This past week the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee voted to move both Congressman Zinke (Interior Secretary nominee) and Governor Perry (Energy Secretary nominee) to the Senate floor for final confirmation. I look forward to partnering with Congressman Zinke and Gov. Perry, who will lead departments that contribute significantly to our nation’s economic prosperity and national security. I am eager to work with Congressman Zinke to restore balance and trust to the management of our public lands, and with Gov. Perry to address challenges such as high energy costs in rural Alaska.
So great to chat with an impressive group of Fairbanks women this morning on what we can do to improve the community. I was so inspired by their energy!
Beautiful day in Fairbanks.
With my cousins last night at the Challenge Alaska Xtra Tuf extravaganza. Alaska style is always special. My sea otter boot toppers were a hit. Cordova made!

This past October I visited LeeShore Center, the domestic violence and sexual assault facility serving the northern Kenai Peninsula, to see firsthand the critical work they do. I’m happy to hear that they are receiving much-needed support so they can continue providing care for women and their children who have been victimized by domestic violence and sexual assault.

Although I did not vote in favor of Betsy DeVos for Education Secretary, now that she has been confirmed by the Senate it is important that we work together as she takes the helm at the Department of Education. We share a common goal that all children receive the best education. I will work with Mrs. DeVos on commitments she made to me during our meetings – to defend state and local control of our schools, to implement federal education laws as they are written, and that she will not undermine or ignore our public schools or force vouchers in any state. I do look forward to her first visit to Alaska as Secretary of Education so she can learn more about the unique challenges and opportunities our schools face.

Healthy oceans and vital, sustainable fisheries are critical to Alaska. Yesterday I sat down with the Oceans Caucus Foundation to discuss my efforts as co-chair of the Senate Oceans Caucus to raise awareness of the issues affecting our oceans, both economic and environmental, to develop policy to address those issues. Whether it’s cleaning up marine debris or cracking down on illegal fishing, I remain committed to strengthening our waters.

I recently joined Senator Amy Klobuchar to introduce legislation to provide vital support to local law enforcement. The COPS Improvement Act will provide for the hiring of more police officers and expand the Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) program to account for developments in community policing techniques that have proven effective in preventing and fighting crime. I am proud to sponsor this legislation to support our nation’s law enforcement officers, acknowledge the risks and sacrifices they make every day, and provide them with the tools they need to keep our communities safe.

Great insight into how the U.S. Coast Guard operates in the ice. As the author states in the article, it “involves more than using the biggest hammer and busting your way through.” We made great progress last Congress to secure the funds needed to construct an Polar icebreaker, but we didn’t quite cross the finish line. I haven’t given up, and I will continue my efforts to modernize our nation’s icebreaker fleet. #BelowZero

I had a constructive meeting today with Judge Neil Gorsuch, President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee, where I had the opportunity to learn more about his background and beliefs as well as educate him on areas of concern to Alaskans. I have been impressed with Judge Neil Gorsuch from the very beginning, and I am now even more confident in his abilities and qualifications as a jurist. Judge Gorsuch will bring a much-needed western perspective to the Supreme Court and can help his future colleagues better understand unique federalism issues facing states like Alaska.
Gave my front desk folks a break and answered some phone calls this morning. It's good to hear from Alaskans weighing in on issues important to them.

#FlashbackFriday to a couple years ago at Kivgiq – an amazing dance festival where villagers from all over the North Slope come together in celebration by dancing, drumming, and singing. I have no doubt Kivgiq 2017 is already set out to be another one to remember. Wish I was there!

Happy to hear the Alaska Eskimo Whaling Commission had a productive and successful meeting this past week in Utqiagvik. I truly admire the hard work of the AEWC to preserve the cultural importance of the bowhead whale and protect their subsistence way of life.

As the aunt of a captain who is out crabbing in the Bering Sea I pray daily for the safety of my nephew and his crew - and all crabbers and fishermen. My prayers are with the family of the crew on board the Destination. God bless and keep safe all those who earn their living from the sea.

Volcanic activity is a part of everyday life for many Alaskans – eruptions at Bogoslof Volcano have sporadically disrupted aviation across much of Southwest Alaska since mid-December. This is why I introduced legislation with Senators Cantwell and Hirono to improve the nation’s volcano monitoring and early warning capabilities, which helps keep communities and travelers safe.
Happy 24th Birthday to my son Matt! While I’m proud to see the man that he has grown up to be, he will always still be my little boy.

Last night the Senate unanimously confirmed Dr. David Shulkin as Secretary of Veterans Affairs. As a member of the Senate VA Appropriations Subcommittee, I have come to know Dr. Shulkin over the past several years. He has a thorough understanding of Alaska’s VA, having seen firsthand the innovative system that was working in Alaska prior to implementation of the Choice Act. I will continue to press Dr. Shulkin on his commitment to continue what has been proven successful in Alaska. I look forward to working with Dr. Shulkin in his new role and have confidence that he will work to ensure Alaska’s veterans have access to quality healthcare, no matter where they live.

A huge congratulations to Zuill Bailey, artistic director of the Sitka Summer Music Festival, on his Grammy win! Mr. Bailey is an extraordinary cellist, and I have had the true honor of listening to him perform live. Alaska is blessed that he is sharing his talent for music with us!

I congratulate Linda McMahon on her new position as Small Business Administrator, and I have confidence that she will work with us to support Alaska’s economy. During our meeting, Mrs. McMahon was interested in the unique dynamics of Alaskan businesses, especially in our rural areas, and assured me that she will be a strong advocate for small business within the new administration. She also expressed interest in learning more about SBA programs that are critically important to Alaskan businesses and the Native business community. I look forward to working with Mrs. McMahon to empower Alaska’s community to support job growth in our state.

I am heartbroken to hear this news, and I will be keeping the crew-members’ family and friends in my prayers . I extend my sincere gratitude and thanks to the Coast Guard and volunteer mariners who dedicated their time, effort, and resources, not to mention putting their own safety at risk, searching for the F/V Destination.
This has been a difficult process for Mr. Puzder and his family. I respect his decision to withdraw.

Today is Elizabeth Peratrovich Day – a day to celebrate one of Alaska’s greatest civil rights activists and female leaders. She worked tirelessly on behalf of Alaska Natives and was a driving force behind Alaska’s first anti-discrimination law back in 1945, when our state was still just a territory. To this day her name represents steadfast hope, perseverance, and landmark change. We are all living in a better Alaska as a result of her fearless fight for equality – something we should remember not just today, but every day.

I am grateful to Alaska Governor Bill Walker for taking an important step forward in the fight against Alaska’s opioid epidemic by declaring it a public health crisis. This will establish a statewide Overdose Response Program under Alaska’s Chief Medical Officer and enables wide distribution of the life-saving opioid overdose treatment drug, naloxone. Alaska’s opioid crisis has devastated so many communities, and this move will provide the tools needed to combat this terrible addiction.

Today I voted to confirm Scott Pruitt as EPA Administrator. As Senator for a state hard-hit by EPA regulations, and chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee that funds the agency, I have a keen interest in who serves as its Administrator. Scott Pruitt has extensive knowledge of the laws that guide the EPA, and he is committed to refocusing the agency on actually cleaning up the environment instead of constantly churning out rules with questionable legal authority. He and I share a common belief that we can be good stewards of our air, water, and land while at the same time growing our economy.  Administrator Pruitt is also committed to engaging state partners in a cooperative manner to ensure that states can protect the environment in ways that make the most sense in their specific circumstances. During our conversations before his confirmation, Administrator Pruitt committed to working with me to find solutions to a number of issues that are important to Alaskans, and I expect him to follow through with that commitment.

It was honor to speak with the National Indigenous Women's Resource Center (NIWRC) to address the scourge of violence against Alaska Native women. We need to actively raise awareness to the issue and to join the effort in delivering justice for the victims and their loved ones. NIWRC does such crucialwork to bring justice to these victims, fighting for a day when no woman is assaulted, raped, murdered, or goes missing. This is what we are fighting for. Thanks to the NIWRC for truly making a difference every day and making our country better and stronger.

Last night was the 40th annual Salute to the Military – a night to honor the men and women who serve our nation in Alaska, the most strategic place in the world. Alaska is home to more than 19,000 active duty service members, another 5,000 in the reserves, and over 5,000 Department of Defense and Department of Homeland Security civilian employees. But we are most proud of the fact that so many who come to serve in Alaska choose to stay, with more than 73,000 veterans live among us now. Salute to the Military is truly one of my favorite events of the year!
Cross country skiing in Girdwood today is fabulous. Perfect conditions for skiing and haiku:       Snow. Lightly, slightly      Brushing all my eyelashes      Winter mascara
So proud of my friend Roscoe on the grand opening of his second restaurant in Anchorage, serving the best soul food in town!
Busy day in Ketchikan yesterday! I started the day by meeting with a group of AARP members to discuss the future of Medicare, Social Security, and the Affordable Care Act.

It was a true honor to meet John Reese, the last Ketchikan resident who can fluently speak Sm’algyax, the Tsimshian language. In 1997, there were 23 fluent speakers in Ketchikan – but that has dwindled to solely Mr. Reese. He is doing such critical work to keep this Native language alive, teaching classes that are free and open to the public through the Ketchikan Indian Community. He did his best to teach me some Sm’algyax words and phrases, and I will long treasure the time I spent with him.

At 11 a.m. I will be delivering my annual address to the Alaska State Legislature, to lay out my vision for our state and share what I'm doing in DC to empower Alaskans. You can watch live on Gavel to Gavel using the link below.

Today I gave my annual address to the Alaska State Legislature in Juneau, outlining my vision for the future of our state and how I am aiming to do everything I can to empower Alaskans. I discussed the future of resource development, healthcare, education, and the military in Alaska. There’s a lot of anxiety and uncertainty out there right now, but I remain confident that the next several years hold much promise for us a state. It’s a long speech, but I encourage you to either watch it below or read the text here: http://bit.ly/2lxcNdI.  http://www.360north.org/gavel/video/?clientID=2147483647&eventID=2017021260&eventID=2017021260
Bumper sticker I saw in Juneau...I couldn't agree more!

Yesterday in Juneau I met with two incredibly innovative Alaskans who are working to make kelp Alaska’s next seafood powerhouse. By harvesting kelp to turn it into salsa and pickles, and looking at other Alaskan products to supplement kelp recipes, these two have found a creative way to make the most of Alaska’s seafood bounty.

I had the honor of announcing the award winners at last night’s Symphony of Seafood. It was not just about sampling seafood (while an added bonus), it was a night full of celebrating  entrepreneurs and innovators. Congrats to those who put so much energy and heart into personal development of seafood products.

So sad to hear that this will be the Alaska Aces last hockey season. The team has been such an important part of Anchorage’s community – from their engagement with young Alaskans to their philanthropic activities. And of course, like many Alaskans I always loved going to their games! Such disappointing news for the Cowbell Crew.

In my effort to visit every school in the state, I spent time at Glacier Valley Elementary School, where I not only had the opportunity to meet with students, but also witness firsthand the incredible work of Lorrie Heagy, a music teacher and Director of the Alaska Music Matters (JAMM) program. JAMM is a tuition-free music program, which uses the power of music and the social experience of ensemble to help youth reach their fullest potential.  Warning -- the kids were enthusiastic with their violins, might want to turn your volume down.

Today marks Denali National Park and Preserve’s centennial! 100 years ago today, President Woodrow Wilson signed the bill establishing Mount McKinley National Park. The Park protected North America’s tallest mountain, Denali, and has inspired Alaskans and visitors from across the nation and the world ever since.

Last week the Conference of Parliamentarians of the Arctic Region met in Anchorage – a group of representatives from the Arctic nations (Canada, Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Russia, Sweden, and the U.S.). We discussed a wide range of issues, from unmanned aircraft systems to scientific research to Arctic policy under the Trump administration. Always great to meet with folks who are focused on our Arctic potential.
Had a wonderful time at the Safari Club International’s Hunting Expo and Sportsmen’s Banquet this weekend, celebrating Alaska’s hunters, fisherman, and outdoorsmen.
This morning I hosted a “Coffee With Constituents” in my new office to chat with the many Alaskans who are in DC this week!

Tonight, President Trump is delivering a speech in front of a joint session of Congress. In his speech, we are told he is going to lay out an optimistic, but realistic, vision for the country. While this is an address directed to Congress, it is also a message for all of us, the American people. His address starts at 5pm Alaska time, and I encourage everyone to watch if they can. I will be watching it live here at the Capitol, and know that I will be listening intently to hear what he has to say, and how he plans on moving our country forward. You can watch it live here through my Facebook page.

Tonight was an important night, for the President, Congress, and the American people. I pride myself as one who believes in the traditions of the Senate. But it is not the tradition of the Senate to filibuster a U.S. Supreme Court nominee. As much and as deeply as I care about bipartisanship in this body, I will not acquiesce to an effort to deny Judge Gorsuch a seat on the Supreme Court. And I acknowledge my friends on the other side of the aisle who have indicated that they will not support a filibuster, and I implore those of my colleagues who have indicated that they will filibuster the nomination of Judge Gorsuch to reconsider that position.

I respect the traditions of the Senate. But it is not tradition to filibuster a Supreme Court nominee – a strategy the Senate Democrats sadly decided to employ today. I have a longstanding practice of supporting a process that allows every nominee the opportunity for an up or down vote once they have been passed out of committee. I also have a long history of working across the aisle to build consensus. But, consensus can only be reached when there are willing parties on both sides and with the Democrats’ decision to filibuster Judge Gorsuch, there was simply no other way to get an exceptionally well-qualified individual through the process without changing Senate rules. It is discouraging and disheartening that it has come to this but Judge Gorsuch is before us, his qualifications are unquestionable, and I believe we need to move forward to restore a fully functional Supreme Court.

Beautiful sight of the Commissioning of the U.S. Coast Guard Cutter John McCormick in Ketchikan, the first fast response cutter stationed in Alaska. This vessel and crew will be a valuable asset to keeping those that use our waters safe.

I am proud to have introduced the Offshore Production and Energizing National Security Alaska (OPENS) Act with Senator Dan Sullivan, which repeals Outer Continental Shelf (OCS) withdrawals made at the end of the Obama administration, provides for lease sales in the Arctic OCS, and ensures Alaska receives a fair share of the revenues from oil and gas development off its coast. After years of burdensome regulations and restrictions, this bill is essential for plotting a better course for responsible energy production in our Beaufort and Chukchi seas. I look forward to working with Alaskans and my colleagues in the Senate to advance this bill to develop this region responsibly to the benefit of Alaskans and our nation as a whole.

It was great to be at the Arctic Encounter Symposium in Seattle with so many distinguished Arctic experts. This event is valuable to advancing our discussions about the Arctic and taking advantage of the emerging opportunities in the continually evolving region. This weekend I met with health care providers and toured the NICU at the Children’s Hospital at Providence in Anchorage. Thank you to the men and women who provide such critical care to our Alaskan families.

Great to see Alaskans in action working towards bettering opportunities for Alaska’s youth by holding a Kids2College Day. Events like this one are a great way to educate students identify career interests, strategize their learning style, create career plans, and understand the steps necessary in school to begin carving a path for college and future success.
Spending the day in Deadhorse. Beautiful flight up passing over the Brooks Range. Landed in 6 degree weather with a wind chill of -30.

The UAF School of Management honored Business Leader of the Year, Steve Lundgren. Steve is a valuable community member and leader. Fairbanks is fortunate to have him. Congratulations Steve on this well-deserved honor.

I was proud to join Senator Dan Sullivan and Congressman Don Young at the launch of Phase 1 of the Quintillion fiber system up in Deadhorse. Being connected is everything in the new economy, and it's inspiring to see how Alaskan companies have invested in the future of our state. By delivering high-speed internet, companies like Quintillion are not just increasing access; they are providing the means to improve the basic health, educational and economic opportunities available to Alaskans in their communities.

In my continued effort to visit every school in the state, I had a fantastic visit to Meade River School in Atqasuk, where I met a group of bright young Alaskans working diligently to sharpen their minds! I want to thank the school and the students for being so welcoming today; it was a truly inspiring experience, and visiting schools is something I always appreciate while back in Alaska.

It was an honor to be in Utqiagvik yesterday as the community harvested the first whale of the season. It’s such a spiritual occasion, and it was an incredible opportunity to witness this centuries-old tradition.

Had a great time visiting Mat-Su Career and Technical High School today and touring the new building. The school offers so much diversity for different pathways, by providing career/tech preparation for Building, Business, Fitness, Health, Hospitality and Tourism, Transportation and Natural Resources in addition to core academic subjects. It’s great to see so many new unique opportunities for Alaskan students to take advantage of!

I had the chance to visit Nugens Ranch in the Mat-Su Valley, which serves and provides treatment for adult men and women to help break the devastating cycle of drug and alcohol abuse. It was a privilege to meet the staff of Nugens Ranch and speak with the individuals who are taking these steps to get their lives back on track.

I appreciate the time I had at the Wasilla Senior Center today to speak openly with some of our older Alaskans about the issues that impact them the most. I visited with folks on a number of key areas of concern to them, including answering several questions on the healthcare front. It was informative to hear their perspective on federal issues impacting Alaskans.

I am pleased to have co-sponsored a resolution that recently passed the Senate, designating April 15-23 as National Park Week. Admission for all national parks this upcoming weekend is free, so don't miss your chance to get out there and enjoy our public lands.

I received an up close and personal look at the Beacon OHSS Fire Training Facility in Kenai, the sole FAA-certified regional fire training center in the state. What a valuable service this facility provides to training crew for aircraft rescue and fire fighting capabilities using realistic fire-training scenarios.

In Kenai, I spoke at the Alaska Support Industry Alliance summit about the need for our resources in global markets, our ability to produce more, and what it will take to bring our resources to market. I'm excited to work with this new administration to access our resources and to responsibly develop them for the good of our state and nation.

I held a round-table discussion with the Kenai Peninsula Builders Association to talk about how we can provide certainty at the federal level in the midst of the tough fiscal times our state is going through. This was a great opportunity to discuss topics such as overburdensome regulations and the general state of the economy from the homebuilder’s perspective. I really appreciate these meetings to gain a necessary perspective on building issues, and I look forward to addressing the problems we discussed.

I congratulate Gov. Sonny Perdue on his successful confirmation to be our nation’s next Secretary of Agriculture. We had a very good conversation about the many ways in which the USDA impacts Alaska, and he expressed a real willingness to work with us to improve our food security, rural economic development, and the management of our national forests. He knows it is imperative to increase timber production and energy development on those federal lands, particularly in southeast Alaska. Governor Perdue has a long, successful track record as a leader in government and small business, and I am confident he will be a good partner for our state.

Earlier today I met with a group of bright young West Valley High School students visiting our nation’s capital to compete in Nationals for the We the People: The Citizen and the Constitution Program. This program promotes civic competence and responsibility for the nation’s upper elementary and secondary school students, as these young men and women enhance their skills in understanding, reasoning, and responsiveness while learning about the government, the Constitution, and the Bill of Rights. We had a very productive meeting discussing cancer care in interior Alaska, specifically focusing on the impacts of cancer on Alaska Native populations, what delivery and access to treatment looks like for interior Alaska, how the workforce needs impact patients, and what are the most pressing needs for rural Alaskans. The folks living in interior Alaska are far better off because of the incredible work the FCCP does every day.

President Trump signed an Executive Order today directing the Interior Department to review the national monuments designated over the past two decades. During the past administration, we saw sweeping designations that routinely came with complete disregard of local concerns and opposition. This review is a good step forward in our efforts to reform the monument designation process to ensure the concerns of those who stand to be impacted are heard and respected.

I extend my heartfelt congratulations to the crews of Air Force Rescue 466/471/2108, the Guardian Angel team Bruin 01, and members of the Alaska Rescue Coordination Center for winning the Jolly Green Association Rescue Mission of the Year. They're being honored for their exemplary service during a four-day effort to rescue stranded individuals on the Harding Icefield on the Kenai Peninsula. The second Executive Order signed by President Trump today directs the Secretary of Education to review all regulations, guidance and documents issued by the Department to ensure they comply with prohibitions against federal control of our schools put in place by the Every Student Succeeds Act.  Simply put – the law returns control of education decisions to those closest to students and gets the federal government out of the way. It empowers parents, educators, and students, and it gives our local communities more control on what they believe their educational system should look like.

I had the pleasure of meeting Bob Williams, the first Alaskan ever to be inducted into the National Teachers Hall of Fame. He is an outstanding example of a teacher who has created an environment of respect and success, encouraging his students to be innovative, creative, and to strive for greatness. He has earned the admiration of his colleagues, students, and their parents through his hard work and dedication to bettering the lives of those around him by making learning fun and exciting. Williams is a fantastic role model and educator, and I am extremely proud of his achievements and the work he has done to improve the lives of young Alaskans.

Today Alexander Acosta has been confirmed as the next Secretary of Labor, someone who I believe is well-qualified to lead the U.S. Department of Labor.  He has earned a strong reputation among his former colleagues at the National Labor Relations Board and among labor leaders as experienced, fair, and open-minded—someone who understands the relationship between employers and workers and cares about the lives of average Americans.  In my interactions with Mr. Acosta, I believe he truly recognizes Alaska’s unique challenges and opportunities and I look forward to working with him in his new role as Secretary of Labor.

Today Senator Dan Sullivan, Congressman Don Young, and I joined Vice President Mike Pence and Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke as President Trump signed an Executive Order to implement an America-First Offshore Energy Strategy.  The order lifts leasing withdrawals imposed on Alaska’s Arctic, directs the Department of the Interior to conduct a review of the areas available for leasing, and directs a review of certain regulations governing offshore development. After the last administration spent eight years systematically closing off access to the Arctic, this executive order puts us back on track to explore and ultimately produce the prolific resources in that region. Alaskans broadly support offshore development in the Arctic. When President Trump took office, he promised to listen to the people and to return power to them, and today he and Secretary Zinke delivered for Alaskans.

The most effective model for schools is one in which principals are innovative instructional leaders, aiding both teachers and students to grow and flourish in a positive learning environment.  So it was a great pleasure to sit down recently with Lisa Parady, Executive Director of the Alaska Council of School Administrators; Mary McMahon, Principal at Colony High, and Dan Carstens, Principal at Nikiski Jr/Sr High, who travelled to Washington, D.C. on behalf of Alaska’s secondary school principals.  They shared with me the importance of maintaining funding under the Safe and Secure Rural Schools Act and Title II Supporting Effective Instruction State Grants.  We discussed how principals are involved in implementing greater local control of our schools following passage of the Every Student Succeeds Act, and reviewed the impact of the shortage of teachers and the value of Career and Technical Education in our K-12 schools.  All kids deserve a great education, and discussions like this are critical to improving education across Alaska.

SRS provides necessary funding for services ranging from public schooling to emergency services and roads in Alaska. This bill is a temporary fix to long-term problems that demand policy reforms, but as we pursue those, it will help keep our forest dependent communities whole.

Chris Apassingok, a 16-year-old on St. Lawrence Island, was credited last week with catching a 57-foot bowhead whale for his community. Chris has been recently harassed on social media by people from the Lower 48 who don’t understand the traditions of Alaska’s Native cultures, so I wanted to show my support for him, and I encourage others to do the same.   When it comes to whaling, this is not a sport. It is part of a culture that goes back thousands of years. The sharing of a food resource allows people to continue to live in an area with extraordinarily high costs. With this whale, Chris provided for his family and his community – a true honor, especially for a 16 year old. So I cannot stand by as Chris is attacked by people outside of Alaska who know nothing of his culture, the importance of subsistence, or the rich traditions of our Native people. They are bullying a young man for providing for his community, when instead he should be honored for his achievement. My message for Chris is a simple “thank you” as he navigates life in two different worlds. And know that him, his family, and his community have my support.

I can’t overstate the importance of Alaska to the military, as our state’s strategic location is critical to protecting and defending our nation, deterring potential aggressors, and participating in direct military actions if necessary. This bill provides funding for a wide variety of military programs that will allow our military to do its job efficiently and effectively in our state, from providing robust funding to sustain a missile defense interceptors at Fort Greely, enable the retention of the Army 4-25 Brigade at JBER, support for F-35s, and new Coast Guard investments in Alaska. It’s encouraging to see increased funding for our military so that we can best provide for the common defense and effectually protect our nation and our interests.

Today Anchorage honored the men and women of law enforcement on the occasion of the Alaska Police Memorial Day. This year special tribute was paid to the sacrifices of Sergeant Allen Brandt, Fairbanks Police Department, who gave his life in the line of duty last October. With the addition of Sergeant Brandt, the Alaska Police Memorial lists the names of 68 Alaska officers who have given their lives in the defense of our communities and our people. Behind each and every one of those names is a story of valor and selflessness. These stories remain matters of great pride to the families of the fallen who return to honor their loved ones each year. And they are stories that can never be forgotten.

Today kicks off the "Week of the Arctic", with more than 1,000 people from around the world meeting in Fairbanks for the Arctic Council. The Arctic Council is a forum of eight Arctic nations, including the United States, and serves as a venue for a collaboration of issues throughout the Arctic region. The week will be an opportunity to speak with leaders from Alaska and around the world to discuss important Arctic issues such as broadband, economic development, science and research, and community resilience. I look forward to Alaskans showcasing our ways of life, priorities, and perspectives during the week.

Last week the Senate voted on the omnibus appropriations legislation to fund the federal government through the remaining fiscal year. I was pleased to be able to include provisions to address a wide range of challenges, needs, and opportunities in Alaska, including the approval of the time-sensitive Alaska Mental Health Trust (AMHT) land exchange to conserve the scenic backgrounds of communities such as Ketchikan, Petersburg, Sitka, Wrangell, and Juneau; provide much-needed timber supply to Southeast timber mills; and provide benefits to vulnerable populations in Alaska. The exchanged AMHT lands will be added to the Tongass National Forest, and the lands AMHT receives may be used to generate funds for the mental health system. This is a widely supported, common sense solution that will deliver real economic and environmental benefits for Southeast communities. It has been a top legislative priority of mine, and I glad to see this triple-win for Alaska over the finish line.

I appreciate the Majority Leader’s commitment to working with Senator Dan Sullivan and me to reauthorize the Secure Rural Schools program, which helps resource-dependent communities with tax-exempt federal lands to provide essential public services. In Alaska, many communities in the Tongass and Chugach rely on these payments to fund vital services such as public schooling, emergency services, and road maintenance. In the short term, Congress must work together to continue the SRS program and, at the same time, we must find better solutions in the long-term that will help provide the jobs and economic activity our rural and forested communities so desperately need.

Like many Alaskans, I’m concerned about the continuous and often conflicting reports about President Trump, the FBI and Russia. The American people deserve to know the truth. I still maintain that the Senate Intelligence Committee should continue conducting a thorough and fair investigation. At the same time, it’s imperative that we – Congress, the FBI, the Administration – work to restore the public’s trust. In order to gain that credibility, it may be that we need to look to an independent commission or special prosecutor.

I recently spoke about the importance of National Police Week, when we remember and honor the officers made the ultimate sacrifice in the lines of duty, including fallen Officer Allen Brandt of Fairbanks. This is a time to focus on how they lived their exemplary lives, pay our respects, and look to help those who have suffered a law enforcement tragedy to grieve and ultimately recover. I offer my sincerest condolences to Natasha Brandt and her family, Office Brandt’s colleagues, and to the loved ones of fallen law enforcement members everywhere.

I am pleased to see that the Deputy Attorney General has appointed former FBI Director Robert Mueller, an individual of uncompromising integrity, as Special Counsel to lead the Russia investigation. This is a positive step towards restoring the public’s trust. This action does not lessen my support for the vigorous oversight and investigations being conducted by the appropriate Senate committees, and I expect that those investigations will run in parallel with the Special Counsel’s work.

150 years ago the United States began coastal survey work to report upon the geography and resources of Alaska. This work was done by the agency now known as National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Corps, which continues the science and survey missions in Alaska that began in 1867.  Their efforts directly influenced the passage of a bill appropriating the money to secure the Territory of Alaska for the United States. Alaska Governor Bill Walker proclaimed today as the 150th Anniversary of the Survey of Alaska and 100th Anniversary of the Commissioning of the Officers of the U.S. Coast Survey and NOAA Corps, to recognize and celebrate the historic actions that led to the Alaska’s statehood.

As co-chair of the Senate Oceans Caucus, today I hosted an event on the importance of ocean acidification research and awareness, and the impact it has on our economy. Over the past decade, ocean acidification has emerged as one of the most prominent marine conservation issues affecting our coastal communities. We need viable strategies to anticipate and respond to future changes brought on by ocean acidification. I thank the National Aquarium education staff and the Ocean Caucus Foundation’s hard work to raise awareness of issues impacting our oceans, and I remain committed to strengthening the protection of our waters.

Today I questioned Admiral John Richardson of the U.S. Navy on concerns from Alaskans regarding the Northern Edge military exercise conducted in the Gulf of Alaska. I asked what the Navy plans to do going forward to address these concerns and grow its trust with coastal communities. Admiral Richardson assured me that the Navy is listening to Alaskans’ concerns, considering re-scheduling the exercise to the fall, and is dedicated to ensuring that our state's waters and fisheries are protected.

Speaking on the Senate floor to congratulate the U.S. State Department, the people of Fairbanks, and the Alaska Arctic Council Host Committee for a successful Arctic Council Ministerial Meeting in Fairbanks. I am also discussing the accomplishments and challenges of the Arctic Council during the United States’ recent chairmanship, and to look ahead at what I hope and expect will be our nation’s continued leadership in the Arctic.

I was pleased to join Congressman Young and Senator Sullivan today to hear from 13 bright, dedicated young students from Nenana City School District. These students shared their personal experiences with Nenana’s STEM (science, technology, engineering and math) education program and discussed how it has helped them to prepare for their futures. The school district’s leadership, in partnership with Tanana Chiefs Conference, has had the vision to begin this K-12 program, initially funded by the Alaska Native Educational Equity Program (ANEP). It helps prepare students at both the city and the boarding schools for careers in aviation, biomedical science, automation/robotics design, and engineering. I am so proud of what these young men and women have achieved through their STEM education, and I will continue to support ANEP as well as STEM initiatives that empower Alaska’s youth, providing them better opportunities for their future endeavors.

While Secretary Ryan Zinke was in the state, we had a chance to tour the Nike Site Summit near Fort Richardson. It was built back in 1958 during the Cold War to defend Anchorage against a potential attack by nuclear armed Soviet bombers. Today I traveled to Unalaska to commemorate 75 years since the Aleutian Campaign during World War II. The Battle of Dutch Harbor occurred on June 3 and 4, 1942 when the town was attacked by Japanese bombers. Three days later, Japanese forces invaded and captured Attu and Kiska islands in the Aleutian chain – marking the first foreign occupation of American soil since the War of 1812. During WWII, the Unangax (Aleuts) were forcibly evacuated from their villages and were relocated to Southeast Alaska – living under dreadful conditions and resulting in the loss of knowledge of many of their traditions. Today in Unalaska, we will remember these events that shaped the history of this part of Alaska.    I began my day in Unalaska with a traditional Unangax lunch, attended by World War II veterans and survivors of internment. It was remarkable to hear their stories and first-hand accounts of this time in history.

Yesterday I joined many other Alaskans to remember the impacts of World War II on Dutch Harbor, the Aleutians, and the State of Alaska as a whole. I was humbled to honor and acknowledge all who made sacrifices and suffered in the war – the Unangax people who were taken from their homes, the soldiers and sailors who made the ultimate sacrifice on the Aleutian Islands, and the many Alaskans who answered the call of duty. Their sacrifices secured the future we enjoy today.

This last Friday we lost former Alaska Attorney General Grace Berg Schaible, who passed away at 91 years old surrounded by friends and family in her home in Fairbanks. Schaible was the first woman to serve as Attorney General of Alaska, although she may be better known for her philanthropy and vast contributions to the University of Alaska. Grace donated more than $1 million to support the University of Alaska Museum of the North, as well as numerous pieces of art and other valuable additions to the school. She not only attended UAF, but proceeded to support it long afterwards. An Alaskan legend has left us, and we will never forget a woman who gave us so much to remember.

We discussed energy innovation in Alaska, the high cost of electricity in our state, implementing microgrids in Alaska, improving energy efficiency statewide, and potential investments in biomass, hybrid wind-diesel systems, solar, and more. I believe we must work closely with innovative Alaskans to address energy costs to improve local communities, as well as the state as a whole.

Today I questioned Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein regarding the inconsistency between federal and state marijuana laws. I am encouraged to see tribes, Native corporations, state agencies, and the university campuses come together to help stop these tragedies. Yesterday I chaired an oversight hearing held by the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources to examine the U.S. Department of Energy’s $28 billion budget proposal for Fiscal Year 2018, a $2.7 billion reduction from the current fiscal year. I told Energy Secretary Rick Perry that while I understand what drove this proposal and appreciate the need to derive savings and balance our budget, this cannot come at the expense of our efforts to further science and energy innovation. I am concerned about some of the proposed cuts, including its request to phase out the innovative ARPA-E program. We need to work together to find areas of agreement and opportunities to ensure the next generation of energy technologies is developed here. We need to do a better job of reducing costs of emerging, pre-commercial technologies to make energy more affordable, reliable, clean, diverse, and secure. This is particularly important in Alaska, where energy costs are much higher than in other states. I look forward to continuing to work with the DOE on these initiatives.  https://www.murkowski.senate.gov/press/release/murkowski-doe-must-help-strengthen-us-leadership-in-energy-innovation

Addressing healthcare legislation, I was asked by a reporter about my opinion in working in a bipartisan manner to address problems. The short answer, absolutely. Yesterday the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced a proposed rule to rescind the Obama Administration’s controversial “Waters of the United States” (WOTUS) rule. Some 31 states, including Alaska, sued to block it. I strongly and consistently opposed the rule because it was yet another burden for Alaskans that would have lessened our economic opportunities, stranding projects and capital while leaving confusion and frustration in their place. I will work closely with the EPA on this new rule to ensure local communities are involved in the discussion about how to reasonably protect our waters.

I questioned EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt on the EPA’s budget request for fiscal year 2018. We discussed numerous issues that impact Alaska – ranging from reducing spending at the EPA, air quality issues in Fairbanks, diesel generator regulations, and efforts to keep our air and water clean.  It is my hope that the new Administration will work with us on a number of important matters that uniquely affect Alaskans, and that we will be able to work together in focusing on the core mission of the EPA to clean up the environment in a sensible manner.

I am proud to introduce the Strengthening the Addiction Treatment Workforce Act with Senator Donnelly. This bipartisan legislation allows mental health and addiction treatment facilities to expand their number of healthcare providers to offer better care for those struggling with substance abuse disorders. In Alaska, there are far too many communities that have been devastated by alcohol and substance abuse. This bill could go a long way in helping curb these problems by providing the necessary support and improve both quality and access to care. This bill is also  crucial step towards ending the opioid epidemic and substance abuse in Alaska and throughout the country.

I’m proud to introduce a new bill that will help Alaskans produce more energy, pay less for energy, facilitate needed infrastructure, boost the innovation of new technologies, and protect sportsmen’s access to federal lands—all without raising taxes or adding to the deficit. The Energy and Natural Resources Act of 2017 (ENRA), the successor to my broad, bipartisan bill from the last Congress, encompasses a wide range of Alaska priorities for energy, resource, innovation, infrastructure, and land management policies. It will allow us to tap into more of our world-class mineral base, remove hurdles to the gasline, expand the use of hydropower and other renewables, reauthorize critical programs that provide vital funding, boost Alaska Native energy development, increase sportsmen’s access to federal lands, and protect against natural hazards. This is a bill written by and with Alaskans, for the benefit of our whole state, and I’m eager to work with my colleagues to move it forward.

North Korea’s test of what is believed to be an Intercontinental Ballistic Missile is a matter of grave concern. Equally concerning are reports that the missile has a range that could in theory strike Alaska. The words “in theory” are important because analysts are skeptical of whether this is technically possible. But this is no cause for complacency. This week's events in North Korea further demonstrate the wisdom of recent growth in Alaska's military presence. The decision to retain the 4th Airborne Brigade Combat Team at JBER, the decision to base 54 F-35 “fifth generation” Joint Strike Fighter aircraft at Eielson and the Long Range Discrimination Radar under construction at Clear Air Force station have come as a response to the dangers in Alaska’s backyard. In the coming weeks, the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee on which I sit will take a close look at funding improvements to our ground based missile defenses at Fort Greely. This conversation occurs at a critical time for Alaska and for our nation.

The U.S. missile defense system THAAD performed a successful test yesterday, shooting down an intermediate range ballistic missile. A ballistic missile target was air-launched by a U.S. Air Force C-17 over the Pacific Ocean north of Hawaii. A THAAD weapon system located at PSCA in Kodiak, Alaska, detected, tracked and intercepted the target. Preliminary indications are that planned flight test objectives were achieved and the threat-representative, intermediate-range ballistic missile (IRBM) target was successfully intercepted by the THAAD weapon system. After the test, MDA Director Lt. Gen. Sam Greaves stated, “I couldn’t be more proud of the government and contractor team who executed this flight test today. This test further demonstrates the capabilities of the THAAD weapon system and its ability to intercept and destroy ballistic missile threats. THAAD continues to protect our citizens, deployed forces and allies from a real and growing threat.” This successful test demonstrates Alaska’s geographic importance and critical standing to U.S. missile defense.

This week I introduced the Genetically Engineered Salmon Labeling Act, along with Senators Dan Sullivan, Maria Cantwell, and Jeff Merkley. As I've been saying, the Senate should take a step back and engage in a bipartisan process to address the failures of the ACA and stabilize the individual markets. That will require members on both sides of the aisle to roll up their sleeves and take this to the open committee process where it belongs. The individual market in states like Alaska and in rural communities across America has continued to deteriorate since we last voted to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Alaskans have seen their premiums increase over 200 percent, only one insurer remains on our individual market, and the state was forced to enact a costly reinsurance program to keep our sole remaining provider from leaving. At the same time, the coverage offered on the exchange has become coverage in name only for too many Alaskans with premiums close to $1,000 a month on average and many facing deductibles approaching $10,000. Repealing the ACA without a clear path forward just creates confusion and greater uncertainty. As I stated earlier this year, I cannot vote to proceed to repeal the ACA without reform that allows people the choice they want, the affordability they need and the quality of care they deserve.

Today, I chaired a hearing at the Energy and Natural Resources Committee to examine the status of U.S. and North American energy and resource security - everything from the significant benefits that have resulted from the elimination of the domestic ban on crude oil exports to the need to maintain U.S. nuclear leadership and improve our waning mineral security. Our standing with energy has changed, due to tremendous innovation and technological advances. Our nation has moved away from energy scarcity and isolation to a point where energy dominance has become a legitimate policy goal. Alaska is the most resource-rich state in the nation, and we stand ready to help strengthen our energy security. From domestic production and export policies to potential sanctions on other nations, we have a lot of work to do, which is why hearings such as this help us understand what is happening in global markets and with geopolitics in regards to energy and resources.

This week I spoke at a symposium on the impacts of an ice-diminishing Arctic on naval and maritime operations. Anyone who follows my efforts knows my insistence on the importance of the Arctic to our nation’s interests. We need to encourage and grow our national knowledge of the Far North.  Increased activity in the region as a result of an ice-diminished Arctic is not just a data point; it has real life impacts for those who live in the region. And as we focus on the Arctic, I stressed the need to look at it from a holistic manner to create a win-win for all involved – from research activities , economic development, infrastructure, and environmental stewardship.

Bright and early today, I participated in a discussion on the Arctic, alongside my colleague and fellow co-chair of the Senate Arctic Caucus, Senator Angus King, at a CSIS event – specifically Arctic economic opportunities and limitations. As many of you know well, I feel that we are not doing enough to take advantage of all the opportunities available in the Arctic. To put it bluntly, the Arctic is one of our nation’s most important assets and should be treated as a national priority. I will continue to push for the United States to invest in the infrastructure and assets critical to supporting greater leadership in the Arctic. Discussions, such as this one, are critical to developing an Arctic strategy so we can address regional opportunities and take the actions necessary to be a world leader in the region.

Congrats to Joe Balash on his nomination to be the Assistant Secretary for Land and Minerals Management at the Department of the Interior. Joe is an excellent choice, and I’m incredibly pleased that Secretary Zinke has chosen him for this important position. From his time in the Alaska governor’s office and as commissioner of the Alaska Department of Natural Resources, to his service as a Chief of Staff for my colleague U.S. Senator Dan Sullivan, Joe is uniquely qualified for this role. He has significant experience on energy and resource policy, a demonstrated record of upholding Alaska’s interests as a landowner, and will make sure that America’s interests are well represented at the Interior Department. I am confident he will continue to serve Alaska and our nation well.

Today the House passed legislation to authorize a land exchange needed to construct a short road linking the isolated communities of King Cove and Cold Bay in order to provide local residents with reliable access to emergency medical transportation. I am thankful for Congressman Young’s leadership on this issue and for bringing a life-saving road for the people of King Cove one step closer to reality. After years of needless suffering, including 63 medevacs since December 2013 alone, I am grateful to have bipartisan support in Congress and – finally - an administration that understands why a road is the best and only option to truly protect the health and safety of these local residents.

The Senate Appropriations Committee passed the FY18 Energy and Water Appropriations bill, which provides funding for the Department of Energy programs and critical infrastructure projects administered by the Army Corps of Engineers. Included in the bill are several provisions to address Alaska’s unique infrastructure needs and to promote an innovative and sustainable approach to energy production, as well as a renewed focus on the Arctic region regarding energy innovation and security. Alaska faces unique infrastructural and energy challenges—whether it be due to our state’s vast size, remoteness, difficult terrain, or harsh climate. The provisions contained in this bill will bring to Alaska much-needed investments in infrastructure and energy innovation. This legislation will help so many communities across the nation, including Alaska.

I have been adamantly opposed to the FDA's approval of genetically engineered (GE) salmon, so I am happy to report that I secured a provision in the Agriculture appropriations bill, which just moved out of Committee, to mandate labeling of GE Salmon, or as I like to call it: ‘Frankenfish’. Alaskans will not accept that GE salmon be sold to anyone without clear labeling. As Alaska’s fisheries are world-renowned for their high quality seafood, we know there’s a huge difference between ‘Frankenfish’ and the wild, healthy, sustainably-caught, delicious real thing.  People have a right to know what it is they are feeding their families, and this bill ensures consumers know the difference. #Saynotofrankenfish

Congratulations to The Great Alaskan Bowl Company from Fairbanks for representing our state at this week’s Made America Product Showcase! Owner Lewis Bratcher and his daughter, Emily Berriochoa, shared their products with the President and Vice President from the East Room of the White House this week. Alaskan artists combine beauty and functionality in their crafts, and we are proud to see this Alaskan business recognized on the national stage. #MadeInAmerica
Get out and play to celebrate Ted Stevens Day! There’s no better way to honor the life and legacy of Uncle Ted than enjoying Alaska’s great outdoors.

Today in Kodiak, NOAA held a change of Change of Command Ceremony for NOAA’s ship, the Rainier. I want to thank Commander John Lomnicky and his crew for the important work that they are doing to conduct hydrographic surveys off the Coast of Alaska and welcome Commander Benjamin Evans as he takes command. The Rainier’s mission to collect oceanic data will lead to updated charts, enhanced safety, and is integral to many maritime industries in Alaska. While vessel traffic and activity in the Arctic is increasing, charting of the region remains woefully behind. We must build off of the good work of the NOAA survey fleet and expedite our charting efforts to ensure the safety of the people living and working in the Arctic.

I have repeatedly said that healthcare reform, and especially major entitlement reform, should go through the committee process where stakeholders can weigh in and ideas can be vetted in a bipartisan forum.   I voted ‘no’ today to give the Senate another chance to take this to the committee process.   I still believe that’s the best route, but we will now have this debate on the open floor. We all recognize that we have much work to do to address the healthcare concerns in this country. My commitment is to work with all of my colleagues in the Senate to find solutions that benefit all Americans by increasing access and reducing the cost of care.
