Yesterday, 35 of my Republican colleagues and I sent a letter to Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke in support of the Department of the Interior’s new Outer Continental Shelf Five-Year Oil and Gas Leasing Program for 2019-2024. As we stated in the letter, the offshore leasing program contributes to U.S. energy dominance and benefits the economies of all of the states, helps reduce the federal deficit, provides affordable energy to families and businesses, and strengthens our national security. I look forward to continuing our work with DOI as they advance the new Five-Year Program.

Last night I welcomed Covenant House Alaska, a leader of combating youth homelessness, to my office here in DC. The Alaska Covenant House is an important resource for our state’s homeless youth, helping them transition from crisis to independent living. Yet Covenant House exists as more than just food and lodging, It’s an investment into our state, our culture and our future. It’s giving some of our transitional neighbors a helping hand when it comes to a job interview and provides housing and security as they recover from destroyed or damaged homes. I appreciate everything the Alaska Covenant House does for our state and I will continue to support their critical services.

I voted no on the healthcare proposal last night because both sides must do better on process and substance. The Affordable Care Act remains a flawed law that I am committed to reforming with a structure that works better for all Americans. But to do that, the Senate must fully devote itself to an effort to improve the healthcare system in this country, reduce costs, increase access, and deliver the quality of care that our families want and deserve. I know that access to affordable care is a challenge for so many. I hear from fishermen who can’t afford the coverage that they have, small business owners who can’t afford insurance at all, and those who have gained coverage for the first time in their life. These Alaskans have shared their anxiety that their personal situation may be made worse under the legislation considered this week. As a Senate, as leaders, we have an obligation to do better for those whom we serve. I stand ready to begin work with my colleagues – all of them – to reform healthcare in a more open process.

This week I had the opportunity to meet with 13 year old Arianna Alrez, a passionate young advocate for the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation (JDRF). These programs provide for not only the continued growth but also the maintenance of Alaska’s rural transportation systems. The committee also approved funds for vital housing programs that help many at-risk populations through housing and community development initiatives. The Appropriations Committee approved a bill that underscores the importance of developing Arctic navigation and infrastructure, marine and aviation operations, as well as our state’s fisheries, coastlines, and water. The Commerce, Justice, Science appropriations bill will further ensure the safety of Alaskans and work towards securing a positive future for important industries to our state.

Last night the Senate confirmed Christopher Wray as the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). Wray has distinguished himself both as an outstanding federal prosecutor and a preeminent criminal defense attorney. The 92-5 confirmation vote on the Senate floor demonstrates the overwhelming confidence my Senate colleagues and I have in Wray’s abilities to successfully lead the FBI. I look forward to working with Mr. Wray in the near future addressing law enforcement challenges we face in Alaska.

Reports suggesting that I blocked the President’s ability to make recess appointments during the August state work period are false and amount to fake news. The Senate passed legislation that I cosponsored with Senator Dan Sullivan that gives terminally ill patients an alternative route to treatment by providing patients options to access investigational agents not yet approved by the FDA. We must exhaust all options and use every tool in our toolbox when providing support for those fighting terminal illnesses. Individuals and their loved ones who are dealing with fighting terminal illnesses need all the help they can get. My hope is this bill will provide support to not only the individuals with terminal illness, but also to their families and loved ones seeking answers to their struggle.

Happy Birthday, U.S. Coast Guard! Alaska’s U.S. Coast Guard Unit, the 17th District, encompasses over 3.8 million sq. miles and over 47 thousand miles of shoreline, and saves an average of 24 lives a month. Yesterday I visited Savoonga on St Lawrence Island in the Bering Sea to see the opening of their new health clinic. The residents of this island live such a unique lifestyle and consequently have unique needs. The Norton Sound Health Corporation, along with local community members, have been hard at work to secure new clinics both here in Savoonga and in the neighboring village of Gambell. These new facilities will provide invaluable improvements in providing quality, modern healthcare. I appreciate the work the Norton Sound Health Corporation is doing to provide such a crucial service for so many Alaskan families.

I spent the morning meeting with representatives from the Alaska Trucking Association. With nearly 33,000 employees in Alaska, the trucking industry is a vital component of our state's economic livelihood. We spent time talking through issues surrounding infrastructure funding, work-to-rest requirements of drivers, and the need for programs to address driver shortages throughout our state. I am so appreciative of the Alaska truckers- thank you all for keeping things moving!

I had the opportunity to tour the Clare Swan Early Head Start Child Care Center in Anchorage this afternoon. This is a unique early childhood education center that offers full day/full year early learning and child care for up to 72 Alaska Native and American Indian children and is using an impressive new teaching model. The center also provides on-the-job training slots for adults pursuing a Child Development Associate degree. Thank you for allowing me to see, first-hand, how your staff is working to nurture and support future generations of Alaskans.

Thinking of my dear friend Ted Stevens tonight, remembering seven years ago we lost an Alaska great. I and all Alaska, miss him and appreciate him so greatly for all he did and all he gave for Alaska.

I had the opportunity to visit Prestige Care and Rehabilitation Center of Anchorage, a nursing and care facility dedicated to serving the health and well-being of its residents and patients.  During my visit I was able to see to see the wide range of care they offer, from assisted daily living to assessment and treatment.  Visiting with residents about their personal stories and their experiences showed me the level of care Prestige provides. It was also inspiring to see their staff working so diligently to support the physical, emotional, and social well-being of the patients they care for.

Happy Alaska Wild Salmon Day, everyone! It’s nearly impossible to think about our great state without thinking about this valuable resource. Salmon puts food on our tables, enriches our culture, provide thousands of jobs, and is a staple of our unique Alaskan traditions. Whether they’re in the rivers and bays, on a plate, or in your freezer- I hope everyone has a chance to enjoy some delicious salmon today!

Hatred, racism, anti-semitism, and bigotry are not welcome in America, and will not be condoned. I am appalled by the news coming out of Charlottesville. We are a nation of one, united, committed to freedom and equality. Charlottesville is not the first time America has been confronted with such unacceptable horror. And like before, America will not back down from her commitment to standby what is right, standing by humanity; protecting the rights and equality of all citizens. My thoughts and prayers are with Charlottesville.

I had the opportunity to tour the Fast Response Cutter (FRC) Bailey T. Barco today with USCG Lieutenant Frank Reed. The cutter was commissioned in Juneau but is stationed in Ketchikan. This multi-mission patrol vessel is  capable of traveling almost 3,000 nautical miles and capable of performing law enforcement, search and rescue, fisheries and environmental protection, and homeland security tasks. Thanks to all the Coast Guard for everything they do to protect and serve this great nation.

The cut flower industry in the U.S. generates tens of thousands of jobs and has a major impact on our nation’s agricultural economy. Because of this positive impact, the Senate recently passed a resolution dedicating July as “American Grown Flower Month” to encourage Americans to support farmers and small businesses who engage in the cut flower market.  While Alaska might not immediately come to mind when you think flowers, we are gaining global recognition for our newly developing peony industry. I am so pleased that my colleagues have agreed to share in my pride for America’s cut flower industry and all the beauty it adds to our communities.

Today in Ketchikan, I had the opportunity to visit the Saxman Senior Center (Shaan Hidi) and tour their newest facility. Great opportunity to see firsthand how they’re serving Alaska’s older generation.

I enjoyed a tour of the Ketchikan Indian Community Mental and Behavioral Health Complex and getting to see the renovations that are underway. KIC Behavioral Health is a clinic that emphasizes Native cultural values, family preservation, and holistic wellness. Their program offers a variety of mental health and substance abuse services for Alaska-Native and non-Native children, adolescents, adults, and families. I appreciate KIC for working so hard to serve the emotional, mental, and physical needs of the Ketchikan community.

Students are gearing up and heading back to school, so I wanted to highlight a very special milestone for a school within our great state. In 1917, a bill was passed to create “The Alaska Agricultural College and School of Mines.” One hundred years later, the university has a new name, but the same relentless mission for teaching and discovery. Thank you University of Alaska Fairbanks for 100 years of hard work. Our state is so grateful for your facility and the staff that support it.

What the President said yesterday was wrong. There is no moral equivalence between those who are inciting hate and division and those who took to the streets to make it clear that those views are unacceptable. Every one of us must stand against hatred, bigotry, and violence, in both our words and our actions. We all have the responsibility to unite and heal our country.

It’s #NationalHealthWeek, which made my visit to the Bethel Family Clinic even more special. This center offers a range of primary care services including family check-ups, labs, behavioral health assistance, physicals, and contains a small dispensary to help ensure commonly needed medications are available to the community. The clinic is focused on serving everyone in need and will not refuse anyone based on ability to pay. I am proud of the integrated healthcare the Bethel Family Clinic is providing and thankful they are promoting wellness for all people within the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta.
I am saddened for the victims in #Barcelona and the family and friends of those affected by this devastating attack. America stands with our friends in Spain.

I had the opportunity to see (and sample) the amazing work of Meyers Farm in Bethel. Tim and Lisa Meyers said they expect they can produce over 100,000lbs of high-quality products this year alone and have a vision to make their product accessible to surrounding areas. They grow everything from lettuce to strawberries and potatoes, selling produce not only in Bethel but in villages across western Alaska. Getting fresh fruit and vegetables to rural Alaska is a challenge, so the Meyers Farm could help bridge the gap in meeting the dietary needs of Bush communities.

I attempted to travel to Crooked Creek this week, but the weather prevented our trip. However, this allowed me the opportunity to turn back and head over to Bethel, where I made a surprise visit to Bethel Regional High School. During my last visit to the school, I ran into students eating lunch in the hallway. When I told them they should be eating in the cafeteria, they informed me they didn’t have one- so we sat in the floor and had lunch together, instead. Since then, I’ve pushed for a cafeteria for these young Alaskans. During my visit I was overjoyed to see the start of construction for the school’s new cafeteria and to have the chance to chat with the students on their first day. I look forward to returning to see the completed cafeteria bustling with students.

I am thankful for the opportunity to celebrate the completion of the TERRA network with GCI and others in Bethel this week. This particular network was built across 223 rivers, 87 lakes, and 6 mountain ranges, to provide high-speed broadband service to over 80 communities and villages in Alaska- a truly impressive accomplishment. This access to high-quality internet service allows development in education, telemedicine, and even aids in facilitating economic opportunities. Congratulations to GCI on this milestone and thank you for keeping us connected!

Reminiscing on my flight with Lt. Gen. Darryl Roberson when he was the commander of the 90th in the late 90's. Congrats on the 100th anniversary of the 90th Fighter Squadron, "Dicemen", and thank you for your service!

In western Alaska this week, I went to visit the village of Kwethluk. It was an opportunity for me to meet with people from the community and listen to their priorities and challenges, from high energy costs to public safety and economic opportunities.  Seeing and hearing it firsthand is key to understanding what's most important to Alaskan families so I can best represent you back in Washington.  It was great to tour the new school under construction -- truly an amazing facility!

Happy to have Deputy Secretary of Energy Dan Brouillette along, and glad that he bought welding glass to look at the eclipse once we were back outside.

I was honored to have Dan Brouillette, our new Deputy Secretary for the Department of Energy, with me to see the best of Alaskan ingenuity. While in Fairbanks, I visited the North Star Ballet School. The Ballet school, home to the northernmost Nutcracker Ballet, has a new home in the Artisan Courtyard after spending decades at the Tanana Valley fairgrounds. I'm grateful for the opportunity to participate in the opening of a deeply moving new exhibit at the Alaska Jewish Museum, this week. The exhibit chronicles an abandoned effort to relocate European Jews to Alaska during World War II. Hundreds, of all faiths, joined to hear Mayor Berkowitz and Diane Kaplan describe the impact of the Holocaust on their own families. Thank you Rabbi Greenberg for bringing us all together to commemorate these tragic events.

It was wonderful to be with Secretary of Transportation Elaine L. Chao in Prudhoe Bay today. This was a great opportunity for the Secretary to see Alaska’s North Slope oil production and the start of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System. We discussed a wide range of important issues, from the need to refill TAPS to pipeline safety and drone use. I'm confident Secretary Chao will be a great partner as we address our state's infrastructure and transportation needs.

As most are aware, our great nation is currently facing an Opioid abuse epidemic. The Alaska State Fair is officially open! I encourage everyone to stop in for food, music & a whole lot of fun. You can even say hello to members of my staff while you're there. #AlaskaFair

From Denali to Glacier Bay to St. Elias- here are some #flashbackfriday photos of time I’ve spent enjoying The Last Frontier!

Today, we not only celebrate what was a major milestone in women’s rights, but also bring focus to our continued efforts for equality. With each year that passes, I am inspired to see more and more women striving to bring a fresh perspective to various leadership roles. I consider myself lucky to get to work with, and represent, such amazing individuals. Happy #womensequalityday to females worldwide and to the men that stand with us in our efforts.
Continued thoughts & prayers to the individuals caught in Hurricane Harvey's path & thank you to first responders & volunteers who are helping the disaster victims.

I recently traveled to the villages of Kobuk, Shungnak, and Ambler, with a brief stopover in Kotzebue,  where I had the opportunity to spend time with community leaders and members and hear from them about the challenges and concerns they face as rural Alaska villages. Some of our topics included their lack of housing, the U.S. Postal Service, and the high transportation and fuel costs. I was so touched by the warm welcomes I received and grateful for the chance to have open, face-to-face discussions about their unique challenges and needs.

In case you didn’t see the news, last week thousands of farmed salmon escaped into Puget Sound. This is just one of the many reasons I’ve opposed farmed salmon, let alone genetically engineered salmon. Escapement from pens is real. The threat they pose to our wild stocks is real. We must ensure the future of wild salmon through proper regulation.

I really enjoyed speaking at the Downtown Anchorage Rotary Club meeting. We covered a range of topics, including the tremendous opportunity we’ve had to bring folks from the Administration to visit Alaska to learn about our unique challenges, firsthand. I spoke to the work we have ahead of us – from my energy and natural resources bill that’s teed up and ready to go, appropriations bills to work on, and a continued focus on our national security. I also talked through healthcare reform and the HELP Committee hearings that will be underway next week. As a member of the this committee, I will make a concentrated effort to assess immediate needs for stabilizing the individual market as well as focus on reducing of the cost of healthcare, long term. Thank you, Anchorage Rotary, for always being such a welcoming and engaging group.
Thank you to all the volunteers helping disaster victims that are being impacted by #hurricaneharvey and a special shout-out to the Alaska National Guard for jumping in to help.

It's always a joy to go to the Alaska State Fair, and this year's visit didn't disappoint. It was great to catch up with so many Alaskans, eat my usual fair food, and check out the incredible Alaska-grown produce and livestock. It's always full of good food, good people, and most importantly lots of Alaska pride!

Thank you to the Greater Wasilla Chamber of Commerce & Palmer Chamber for giving me such a warm welcome yesterday. I was honored to be presented with the "Spirit of Enterprise Award" and grateful for the opportunity to share with you about the partnerships, collaboration, and efforts that have been, and will continue to be, put towards the good of our country.

This week, Set Free Alaska gave me a tour of their amazing new Women’s Residential Center. This multi-generational treatment program helps recovering women overcome the physical and emotional challenges of substance abuse, while creating the whole home life. Their facility has a full kitchen, social rooms, a dinner area, bedrooms for women going through their program, and are currently adding an exercise room, craft area, and a kid’s room. Each room is named after values that the staff hope will be instilled in the lives of women who will come here. It is a truly beautiful center for healing and development. We ended our tour by sitting down with Mat Su Opioid Task Force, Fiend 2 Clean, and The Lazarus Project for an in-depth discussion of their innovative programs and future goals. From using cutting edge technology to providing training for job interviews- these groups have teamed up to support recovering users in every phase of their road to recovery. I am so inspired and so deeply grateful for your passion to address this crucial area of need within our state.

Getting ready to head off the grid to be with my family on our annual duck hunt. My last stop with cell service is this great drive-in where I ran into my good friend Ralph Samuels and shared milkshakes and burgers.

In addressing health care, an intensely personal issue to all Americans and one with significant impact on our nation's economy, it's imperative that everyone is heard. This is why I consistently advocated for regular order while the Senate health care proposals were being drafted so ideas from both parties could be considered and thoroughly examined. That open process is beginning. The Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions (HELP) Committee will hold hearings this week and as a member of that committee, I will be deeply engaged through the process.

I have a firmly held principle that we should not punish children for the actions of their parents. I believe those who were brought to this country by their parents, raised here, educated here, lived here, and dreamed here, should be welcomed to stay here. They should have the right to work and a path to citizenship. That is why I have consistently cosponsored legislation to provide those things, and am heartened to see so many diverse voices supporting a legislative solution for the Dreamers. I am ready to work with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to provide a legal, certain path forward for these children of our friends and neighbors.

The HELP Committee hearing on stabilizing premiums in the individual insurance market takes place today in the U.S. Senate. We’ll hear from 5 state Insurance commissioners, including Alaska Division of Insurance Director, Lori K. Wing-Heier.  If you can’t catch it live, you can watch the archived video here when you have a chance.
Today during the HELP hearing, I asked the state insurance commissioners for their opinions on cost-sharing and how to reduce uncertainty within the market.

With North Korea tensions rising, our missile defenses at Fort Greely have never been more critical to our national security. The Obama administration wanted to mothball one of Fort Greely's three interceptor fields, but in 2010 we prevented that from happening. During a recent visit to Fort Greely’s missile defense facility, I was pleased to see that improvements to the oldest missile field have now been completed -- one of the many contributions Alaska provides to our nation’s security. I am proud of what has already been accomplished at Fort Greely and the level of protection this anti-ballistic missile site offers.

My heart goes out to the countless Americans who are bracing for Hurricane Irma’s fury. Continued prayers for those in the storm’s path, as well as families trying to recover from Hurricane Harvey. I’m proud the Senate passed a crucial Hurricane Harvey aid package today, helping to get emergency aid to victims in desperate need of help. This was an important step in helping Americans get back on their feet towards recovery. Now is the time, as Americans, to band together and help each other find the hope and strength we need to endure these life-changing events.

The Senate Appropriations Committee recently approved a bill that will go a long way in serving Alaskans: providing greater opportunities to gain the knowledge and skills they need and is a direct investment in steps toward improving overall health, including combating our state’s devastating opioid epidemic. Furthermore, this bill will aid families dealing with high home heating costs and provide support for afterschool programs.  As a member of the committee, I am focusing on issues critical to Alaskans, by securing funding for programs that support Alaskan families, jobs, economic development, health, education, and safety.

In conjunction with the 2017 Cancer Programs Conference taking place this weekend, advocates across the nation are supporting #CancerProgramsDay , to highlight issues that impact patients around the nation. Health care is such a personal issues that is relevant to every single person. I hope everyone will take a moment today to appreciate the hard work that goes into our Cancer Programs, both in the state of Alaska, and nationwide.

Working with Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-CA), we recently introduced the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program Reauthorization Act, a bill to reauthorize a national program to improve the nation’s earthquake preparedness. This legislation modernizes earthquake-safety programs that help states prepare for and respond to earthquakes, an issue Alaskans deal with quite frequently. Living in such a seismically active area, we know the dangers we face and the damage and devastation that earthquakes can cause. The reauthorization of the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program will help reduce those risks, increase preparedness, and protect lives by making advanced technologies available in Alaska and around the country.

As JBER based U.S. Army’s 4-25 deploys to Afghanistan in support of Operation Freedom’s Sentinel, I offer my sincerest appreciation for the brave men and women and their families who are dedicated to serving this great nation. I know that they will represent our country well. I will keep our service members and their families in my thoughts and I’m praying for their safe return home.

During the Special Olympics Fall Tournament this weekend, I stopped by the beautiful Special Olympics Alaska facility that opened back in 2014. Wonderful time watching the bocce competition and visiting with athletes.

We pause today to remember those that lost their lives on September 11, 2001, and the friends and families that are still impacted to this day. This solemn anniversary is an opportunity to pay tribute to the first responders and fellow citizens who showed courage and heroism during the aftermath of this attack and to honor the men and women in our military and law enforcement that have and continue to ensure our safety, at home and abroad.

The Armed Services YMCA of Alaska is rallying the troops (or volunteers) in putting on “Operation: Snack Attack” in conjunction with JBER’s 4/25 Brigade deployments. Through “Operation: Snack Attack”, they are providing individually wrapped snacks, water and personal hygiene items to the troops as they leave.  Thank you to all of the service members and their families for proudly serving this country, and thanks to all the Operation: Snack Attack volunteers – including members of my staff – for showing support for our troops.

It was a great weekend to be out participating in the Kenai River Women's Classic. Funding from this event helps ensure fisheries are healthy for generations to come by raising funds for habitat restoration projects, fisheries education, research and management. Beyond that, it’s also a wonderful opportunity to get out on the water and spend some time fishing with many of Alaska’s strong, female leaders. (Special thanks to Fitzgerald Photography for capturing these great memories for us.)

Today I introduced the Boost Saving for College Act with Senator Richard Burr and U.S. Senator Bob Casey. Alaskan families deserve to have the flexibility to meet their own needs with their own money. This legislation will do just that, by helping Alaskans afford college in more ways and getting federal tax penalties out of their way when things don’t go as planned. I am hopeful for the potential this legislation has to help families save for college and successfully map their future. http://bit.ly/2wXQ14n

Today as part of Tribal Impact Unity Days, I spoke to Native American tribal leaders from around the country on current and critical legislative issues impacting American Indians and Alaska Natives, with an emphasis on healthcare, employment, and public safety.  I have worked alongside many of my colleagues to ensure that legislation, such as the Indian Health Care Improvement Act, is and continues to be protected. I also spoke on the importance of my Indian Employment and Training legislation and on reauthorizing the Special Diabetes Program for Indians, both programs that have a proven track record. We still have much to do, but I am proud in the progress we have achieved so far and hopeful for what we will continue to accomplish. Thank you to NCAI for the work you are doing to help us achieve those goals, and thanks to all of the Alaskans who made the long haul to be here.

Last night I had the honor of introducing award-winning composer, lyricist, and performer Lin-Manuel Miranda, as he accepted the 2017 U.S. Capital Historical Society Freedom Award for his dedication to freedom, democracy, and representative government. Mr. Miranda has influenced Americans – young and old, rich and poor, small town and urbanites alike – to be inspired by, learn from, and enjoy the arts. I am proud to congratulate Lin-Manual Miranda for earning yet another recognition, not for the widely recognized strength of his writing or performing, but for his commitment to the strength and value of justice for our nation. Thank you Mr. Miranda for continuing to encourage us all to dream and open our eyes to new possibilities through the arts.

I had a chance to meet with the staff of the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network - Alaska ACS CAN to discuss cancer care and patient advocacy. We had a chance to talk about the dynamics of palliative care, legislation and future funding for the NIH, and the importance of removing barriers to early screening and detection for rural areas of Alaska. Health care can be a complicated, expensive process for citizens of our state, so I am especially appreciative of ACS CAN for striving to be a voice and bridge the gaps for our most under-served areas.
Views from my walk from the office tonight.

Last night was the start of a fabulous new tradition in D.C.--celebrating Alaska wild salmon and its importance to not only our state, but also the world. It was great to be with so many fellow Alaskans to celebrate this staple of our state, to congratulate Bristol Bay on having 60 million salmon return to their fishery, and to celebrate progress we’ve made in supporting and protecting our wild salmon stocks. This bounty, this resource, has sustained not only the Bristol Bay region but our entire state for thousands of years. I have a resolution teed up and ready to go, recognizing the month of September as “Alaska Wild Salmon Month”, which aims to encourage others to help celebrate the sustainable Alaska Wild Salmon industry and all the benefits it provides to our nation. Thanks to Bristol Bay Native Corporation and partners for hosting such a special event.

I am pleased the Department of Energy recognized the ingenuity of Alaskan innovators by awarding a $6.2 million grant to an Alaskan partnership on micro-grids. With significant energy challenges in so many of our remote communities, it is important that Alaskans have a strong partnership with the DOE and the national labs, which will provide more affordable and sustainable energy to Alaskans and Americans in rural communities across the nation.

Both houses of Congress passed a joint resolution that I co-sponsored condemning the violence and domestic terrorist attack that took place in Charlottesville early August. It now awaits the President's signature.The resolution minces no words. Hate and hate groups have no place in American society. It is heartening to see Congress come together and unconditionally reject racism, anti-Semitism, bigotry and hatred. As a nation we neither tolerate the intolerable nor ignore the scar that Charlottesville left on our national fabric. I’m proud to see my colleagues come together in standing for what is right.

Ermalee Hickel was a wonderful woman and great Alaskan. She was gracious and lovely in every way and always treated me with great kindness. When she was First Lady she opened up the Governor's mansion for piano recitals. I never got good enough to have a recital there. I'm still practicing and will think of her fondly when I do. My condolences to her family and loved ones.

This week I introduced legislation with Senator Angus King to renew the national program for geological mapping. Geological maps serve multiple purposes across the nation, including minimizing risks from natural hazards, reducing our nation’s dependence on foreign minerals, and educating our next generation of mappers.

Honored to receive the Voice for Women Award at the Alice Award luncheon, hosted by the National Woman’s Party. This annual event is an opportunity to pay tribute to strong, female leaders that help a voice to women and take action to support them. It was a privilege to be honored alongside fellow Voice for Women award recipient, Senator Tammy Baldwin and 2017 Alice Award recipient, Secretary of Transportation Elaine L. Chao. It was so special to be in a room filled with so many empowering women that I admire.

On National POW/MIA Recognition day, we must #NeverForget the sacrifices they have made in defense of our freedom. Thank you Eielson AFB, JBER, and others for hosting events paying tribute to POW/MIA Recognition Day, for Alaskans to honor prisoners of war, the missing, and their families.

Congratulations to Anna Brown Ehlers of Juneau, this year’s recipient of the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA) Heritage Fellowship - the nation’s highest honor in the folk and traditional arts. Every year the NEA awards fellowship members who go above and beyond to ensure that folk and traditional arts continue to honor our cultures and identities and thrive for generations to come. For more than three decades, Ehlers has taught more than 300 people the art of Chilkat weaving, including mentoring dozens of apprentices in her home. Thank you, Anna, for your dedication to preserving Tlingit artistic traditions and for the beauty your art brings to so many lives.

This Wednesday, the U.S. Small Business Administration is holding a free “Boots 2 Business Reboot” workshop at the Anchorage Chamber of Commerce which introduces Veterans, Service members, and their spouses to develop their entrepreneurial skills. The workshop includes steps to starting a small business, the basics of creating a strong business plan, insight on lenders and investors, and how to develop and implement a business model. Thank you to everyone that supports this program to help veterans establish a foundation for a successful career after serving and protecting the United States.
Happy Birthday to the United States Air Force. Thank you for 70 years of flying, fighting and winning.  I am grateful for your service and all you do for our nation!

Tonight the Senate passed the National Defense Authorization Act, which boosts our nation's defense capabilities and ensures that our military have the resources and tools needed to protect our nation. The defense bill is one of the most significant bills we consider every year. Through this bill, we are enabling our military to protect both our nation and our livelihood. I am particularly proud that the Senate is providing a long overdue pay raise to our service members across the board. We also ensure that the quality of our state’s infrastructure is not limited by our geographic location. I commend my colleague Senator Sullivan for working hard on the Senate Armed Services Committee to secure important resources for Alaska and our nation.

Excellent meeting with Alaska State Trooper Captain Tony April and Dwayne A. Crawford, Executive Director of the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives (NOBLE) about law enforcement – community partnerships. Community safety requires a strong partnership between law enforcement and the communities they serve. And NOBLE members are on the cutting edge of innovation.  I was introduced to NOBLE through Captain April, who serves as a national officer of NOBLE, and value their guidance on law enforcement and criminal justice policy.

The 2017 Southeast Conference -- an annual meeting focused on laying the foundation for economic prosperity in this region -- kicked off today in Haines, Alaska. This year’s highlights include timber, mining, energy, maritime, seafood, tourism, healthcare, and art - all significant contributors to the Southeast economy that I am working hard to support. While I wasn't able to attend to attend this year, several members of my staff are present to learn more about the many promising opportunities we have to boost jobs, earnings, and growth in this key region.

Yesterday, I chaired an Energy Committee hearing that focused on the importance of vegetation management to protect electric grid reliability and prevent wildfires on federal lands. Natural disasters can be damaging to the grid and cause real hardships for people when they lose electricity. One key takeaway is that proper vegetation management around power lines reduces wildfires, which is why it is important for utilities and federal agencies to cooperate so this important work can be conducted in a time-sensitive manner. To help protect our lands and our families, Senator Maria Cantwell and I included a vegetation measure in our broad, bipartisan energy and natural resources bill, which aims to bring timeliness to the federal process for vegetation management and provide expedited access to utilities during emergency situations.

My thoughts and prayers go out to all of those impacted by Hurricane Maria and all those in her path, as well as those dealing with the aftermath of the devastating earthquake in Mexico. Remain strong everyone, and stay safe out there!

The Senate recently passed my resolution, co-sponsored by @Senator Sullivan, recognizing September as “Alaska Wild Salmon Month.” Educating the nation about the impact salmon has on not only our state, but also our nation is so important. This resource has helped sustain Alaska for centuries, and now it will be celebrated nationally for an entire month. Happy #WildAlaskaSalmonMonth, everyone!

Congrats to University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) for receiving a $500,000 competitive grant from the Department of Energy’s Advanced Research Projects Agency – Energy (ARPA-E) program. The grant, which was one of eighteen awarded, will fund a research project focused on the development of scalable coastal and offshore macroalgal farming. I’m optimistic about the potential benefits of kelp production to Alaska, and this grant underscores the importance of programs such as ARPA-E.

This weekend I had the chance to explore the Art of the North galleries in the new Rasmuson Wing at Anchorage Museum at Rasmuson Center. From authentic Alaska Native Art to pink polar bears, this new wing is an amazing addition to already stellar museum that continually strives to connect people, expand perspectives, and encourage a deeper understanding of the North. I hope everyone will take the time to stop by and experience this wonderful exhibit.

This morning I had the honor of introducing my 2017 Angels in Adoption honoree, Rozann Kimpton of Wasilla, Alaska. This program give annual recognition to couples, individuals, and families that have made extraordinary sacrifices and contributions on behalf of children going through adoption or foster care. Rozann became an 81-year old adoptive great-grandparent to her grandchildren, Luke and Amanda, six years ago. In addition to acting as a grandparent, she is volunteer coordinator of the ACRF’s Grandparent Support Group and opens up her home to other adoptive families to facilitate activities for the kids and to foster a sense of community. Thank you to Rozann, and all the other Angels in Adoption, for extending so much sacrificial generosity and encouraging others to do the same.
My statement on the Graham-Cassidy healthcare proposal http://bit.ly/2hxOLl2

Congratulations to Dr. Johnson-Struempler, current Sr. Director of Secondary Education at Anchorage School District and former principal of South Anchorage High who has been recognized as the 2017 Alaska Principal of the Year for her continued excellence in the field. I'm grateful for her dedication to improving the lives of all the students and teachers she works with.
Thank you to the Alaska airmen from the 176th Wing for their bravery and willingness to serve our country. I am praying for your safe return.

We held a hearing in the Senate Indian Affairs Committee to talk about the impacts of human trafficking on American Indians and Alaska Natives and what we can do as a nation to combat this issue in all its forms. This is never an easy topic to discuss, but it is so vital that we educate the public on this very important issue. We must come together to develop practical steps towards supporting victims and ending this heart-breaking issue, once and for all. http://bit.ly/2k5IYnj

I was saddened to hear of the passing of fellow Alaskan, Dr. Nora Keixwnéi Marks Dauenhauer of Juneau. Her dedication to Tlingit history and oral literature was unwavering and widely recognized, both locally and internationally.  Alaska’s Writer Laureate from 2012 to 2014, she was an eminent writer, poet, and researcher of Tlingit culture, language and history.  Although she will be missed, her legacy will live on through her work, generosity of spirit, and wisdom.
Wonderful evening at the 2017 Gala to support the Smithsonian’s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute. I just had to make sure to snag some pics with the stars of the night!

Today I had the opportunity to tour the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, operational home of the Hubble Space Telescope with ASRC. This center plays a crucial role in every area of the agency’s missions, including development, orbit, and beyond. From their testing and integration complex to the robotics operation center, this facility is truly exceptional. I had a wonderful experience learning about the cutting-edge applications of their innovations, as well as their uses in the Arctic and Alaska for sea-ice study and even search and rescue.

Congratulations to the faculty, students, parents, and the rest of the school community of Northern Lights ABC in Anchorage for being named a National Blue Ribbon School! This is a tremendous honor, recognizing your dedication to high academic standards. Everyone involved with this school deserves credit for this exemplary achievement. Keep up the great work!

One of many reasons I'm proud of Alaska, is the resourcefulness of our people. Last week the Alaska Department of Fish and Game officials were forced to euthanize a moose. In many places, the animal might have gone to waste- but not in our state. Students at Haines High School utilized the moose meat for the school’s lunch program, while the bones were donated to the American Bald Eagle Association. It’s great to see the ingenuity of our Alaskan communities. #ThisIsAlaska

ALS is a devastating disease that has touched my family personally. Thankful for all that showed their support today by participating in the Young Faces of ALS (YFALS) Corntoss Tournament. Together, we can offer hope and work towards a cure to one day out an end to this heart-wrenching disease.
Here at the World War II Memorial today and reminded of all who answered the call. The people of Puerto Rico served and sacrificed. We need to be there for them today.
Beyond horrific news out of Las Vegas. I struggle hard to find the words during this difficult times.  My heart goes out to the victims, their families and loved ones. They are in my prayers.

Any loss of life is tragic. And as I said earlier, it is difficult to find adequate enough words to express the sadness I feel for everyone effected by the violence in Las Vegas. But learning this afternoon, two Alaskans were killed, and another in critical condition, truly breaks my heart. As the sun sets in my home state, I mourn not only for our nation, but for Alaska, its citizens and loved ones.

I am incredibly proud to announce that Anchorage School District and Yukon-Koyukuk School District have been awarded two out of the five first-ever Native American Language program grants, funded by a program that I created alongside U.S. Senator Al Franken (D-MN) as part of the Every Student Succeeds Act.  The program is intended to help schools, tribes, and Native organizations create or expand programs in which teaching is provided in the Native language; maintain and promote the right to practice and revitalize their languages, and improve students’ educational opportunities. I’m looking forward to seeing the ways our students and future students will surely benefit from these grant funds in action.

The latest Sturgeon ruling is a hard punch in the gut, and an affront to all Alaskans.  Mr. Sturgeon has fought his way through federal courts for 10 years to secure justice and his right to have reasonable access to lands and waters in Alaska.  His fight has become symbolic of the burdensome and unwarranted use restrictions the federal government has sought to apply in Alaska in recent years. This decision cannot be allowed to stand.  https://www.murkowski.senate.gov/press/release/murkowski-latest-sturgeon-decision-an-affront-to-all-alaskans-

As the termination dust creeps down the mountains, the men and women of Alaska’s snow removal industry are attending the 4th Annual Alaska Snow Symposium hosted by the SnowFighters Institute. Thank you to the dedicated men and women who work tirelessly to keep Alaska’s roads safe in the winter. I hope you had a successful symposium and a white winter!

As Chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, which has jurisdiction for U.S. territories, I want to make sure that the people of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands know that we are here for them, and standing beside them during these exceptionally difficult times. I spoke to how we might help in their long-term rebuild, particularly as it relates to their electric grid and power sector. It must be a priority to work with them, as partners, to make their islands stronger, more resilient, and better prepared for whatever the future may bring.

Incredibly honored to be named one of the 2017 Behavioral Health Champions by the National Council for Behavioral Health. The National Council for Behavioral Health is doing amazing things for the vulnerable people in our communities, and that deserves a recognition.  We’ve made progress surrounding behavioral health in Alaska and across the nation, but there’s much work still left to do. It is crucial for us to try to ensure that we do better than just 'ok' in terms of healthcare -- that we do better when it comes to ensuring that those in need have the assets and support to be healthier Americans.

Tonight, my staff and I had a chance to get together with some of our fellow Alaskans for the Alaska Community Foundation Reception, here in D.C. This organization’s focus is to connect key leaders, companies, and communities to promote philanthropy and develop funding to help meet the unique needs of our state. While I am committed to continuing to fight for healthcare funding at the federal level, it is heartening to know that we have this special organization searching for creative and collaborative solutions and opportunities. Thank you AK Community Foundation for your never-ending effort to “connect people who care, with causes that matter.

As we well know, the U.S. is currently facing an opioid abuse epidemic. While sadly this crisis is no stranger to Alaska, I am encouraged by the discussions we had today in the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (HELP) committee hearing, on the innovative opportunities for prevention, non-addictive interventions for chronic pain, and improved treatment methods for Alaska and the nation.

Today I spoke on the Senate floor about the importance of our nations’ response to the tragedy of missing and murdered Native women and girls. I’d like to thank my colleagues: Senators Heitkamp, Daines, and Tester for their continued efforts on this issue.  I am proud to lend my voice to the proposition that Congress, in the exercise of its responsibility to our Native people, has a responsibility to do more. It is high time that federal law enforcement answer the question why the murder rate for Native women is so high and why we are not addressing it in a comprehensive fashion. We must acknowledge a problem that has failed to make the headlines in this country because remaining silent is simply unacceptable.

Special thanks to the Alaska Air and Army National Guard members that will deploy tomorrow to aid and assist Puerto Rico during the aftermath of Hurricane Maria. So many agencies and organizations have come together to show support, aid in relief efforts, and provide resources; I’m proud to see the brave men and women from our state committed to doing their part to help support this good work.

It’s #FATBEARWEEK, which means it’s time for everyone to cast their vote on the burliest bears in Katmai National Park & PreserveNationalPark. It looks like it will be a close race, but I am officially endorsing Bear 747 and look forward to celebrating his victory. The Champion will be announced Tuesday, October 10th- so be sure to weigh in!

Until very recently, the small town of Nikolai had a big problem: there was nowhere for the high school teacher to live. In our remote communities, housing shortages can be incredibly common. But in true Alaska fashion- the school district came up with an innovative solution. They allowed students in the village, under professional supervision, to build a house for the new teacher during a special summer program. The kids learned about problem solving and hard work, while earning high school and college credit for the class. The success of the project led the school district to plan on expanding to other areas next summer.  Kudos to all involved in this partnership!  #ThisIsAlaska

Proud to see my staff, along with many others, take part in the “Choose Respect March” in Wrangell, today. This event is a simple, meaningful way for our Alaskan communities come together to raise awareness of domestic violence and sexual abuse in the state, and take a stand to end these abusive relationships.
Rain or shine- it's always great to be in Cordova. #Alaska

I had a great time yesterday shadowing Dimond High School Principal, Tina Johnson-Harris, to get a better idea of what her job is really like. After a warm welcome from the students and staff, I toured the school and visited several classes, including a robotics class where I tried out augmented reality equipment. It was also great to meet with students in the Japanese immersion program as well as the members of the student government who shared the challenges they face while governing within the school. I am so impressed by the strong leadership, progressive teaching methods, and healthy learning environment that Dimond High School provides our students. I look forward to seeing all the good work they’ll accomplish together this school year.

I can’t say enough how proud I am of Alaskans that are jumping into action to support Puerto Rico during recovery and clean-up efforts. One great example is Nome’s Sitnasuak Native Corp, which owns SNC Technical Services (SNCT), a defense manufacturing company with two locations in Puerto Rico. CEO Roberta (Bobbi) Quintavell wasted no time in mobilizing her team in Nome to figure out how to help their SNCT employees and families in Puerto Rico over 5,000 miles away, from chartering planes to deliver diesel generators and fuel, communications equipment, camp stoves, and water purification systems just to name a few.  Sitnasuak even converted part of their cafeteria to act as a childcare facility during the day and a shelter for families over-night. Thank you to Ms. Quintavell and her staff for embodying their traditional Inupiat values and taking care of each other- no matter the distance.

It was an honor to help send off 23 veterans as they headed out to Washington D.C. as part of The Last Frontier Honor Flight. This special program honors veterans by flying them to see the memorials built in recognition of their service and in commemoration of their fellow service men and women who are no longer with us. Thank you, on behalf of our state and our nation, for your bravery and sacrifice. I hope you all have a fantastic trip.

The opioid epidemic is wreaking havoc on Alaska and the rest of the nation- affecting nearing 2.6 million Americans. Today U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren and I sent a letter to the President, asking him to formally declare the nation’s opioid epidemic a national emergency.  Our effort to secure more federal support will help states continue the good work already underway in addressing the opioid crisis. We need to do everything that we can to address this national public health crisis and provide those combating this epidemic with the tools they desperately need.

So proud to see Alaskans give such a wonderful ‘welcome home’ to the veterans returning from The Last Frontier Honor Flight.

Fronteras, Mat-Su's Spanish Immersion School, has been celebrating Hispanic Heritage month by recognizing the histories, cultures and contributions of American citizens whose ancestors came from Spain, Mexico, the Caribbean, and Central and South America. Most recently, they held a country flag presentation ceremony that my staff had the opportunity to attend. I’m told each student spoke fluently in Spanish, delivering a brief history of the country. I am so proud of their persistent  hard work and their genuine appreciation for history and culture.
As 2017 King Crab Season begins, I send my thoughts and prayers to my two nephews, the rest of crew of the Brenna A, and to all the crab fleet.‬

“Congratulations to Tara Sweeney on her nomination to serve as Assistant Secretary of Indian Affairs within the U.S. Department of Interior. Tara has a very strong record of professionalism and accomplishment in Alaska, across the country, and internationally, especially with the indigenous people of the circumpolar north. She has significant experience on Arctic issues and chaired the Arctic Economic Council. She is an expert on energy, infrastructure, broadband, economic development, Native self-determination, and a wide range of policy issues that will come before her. Secretary Zinke could not have chosen a better leader to help him fulfill the federal government’s trust responsibility, and I know Tara has the heart and drive to excel in this position.”

For months now, I have been urging a bipartisan approach to healthcare reform. I applaud my colleagues, Senators Alexander and Murray, for continuing to work towards a bipartisan solution addressing some of the most urgent and pressing needs when it comes to the flawed current healthcare law. I’m so pleased to see that the good progress we made in the HELP Committee, in our efforts to stabilize and strengthen the individual market while working to keep premiums from rising, has not stalled. I remain committed to working with my colleagues, on both sides of the aisle, to build upon this progress. This short-term deal is an important step as we work towards long-term solutions.

Many of you may remember Chris Apassingok, a 16-year-old from St. Lawrence Island that was credited with catching a 57-foot bowhead whale for his community, which resulted in widespread harassment on social media by people who don’t understand the traditions of Alaska’s Native cultures. Happy #AlaskaDay everyone! 150 years ago, on October 18th in 1867, Alaska officially became part of the United States. The transfer price for the United States to purchase Alaska from Russia was roughly two cents an acre. The primary advocate behind the Alaska purchase was then Secretary of State William Seward, who had vision of the great contributions Alaska would bring to the U.S. Although the treaty was mocked and Seward was ridiculed at the time, it’s easy to see now that Seward made, perhaps, the best business deal in our nation’s history.

As an Alaskan and the daughter of a Coastie, I’d like to thank all members of the USCG, veterans, and their families for their dedication to protecting not only our waters and interests in Alaska, but throughout the rest of the United States and the world. #CGAK150

This Saturday, October 28th, is National Prescription Drug Take Back Day. In light of the current opioid epidemic we are facing in this country, it is increasingly important to educate the public about the potential dangers of the abuse of medications. Studies show a majority of abused prescription drugs were obtained from family, friends and often from the home medicine cabinet. So this day is set aside as a good reminder to clean out your cabinet as well as provide a convenient, safe way to get rid of your unused or expired meds. I’d like to say a special thank you to my Coast Guard Fellow, Juan Ramirez, for spending the last few weeks serving with the U.S. Coast Guard in Puerto Rico. Juan was a part of a range of projects, from acting as CG Liaison Officer at the Operations Command Center to working with FEMA to transport critical goods, fuel, and personnel in and out of the area. He was also able to support his hometown of San Lorenzo by providing families, including his own, with much needed water, food, and debris cleanup.   When asked for his personal insight after spending time on the ground, Juan told us that the situation is very complicated and things are progressing, but very slowly. “Overall, I think that the biggest issues still facing the island are the need for energy and water, especially for those towns outside of San Juan. It is difficult to piece your life back together and to carry on with your normal day to day without the basic necessities. From my experiences in San Lorenzo, the lack of electricity made everything more difficult. The supermarkets were very limited on what they were carrying because those that were open were running on generators. There were long lines, no ATM system- and without cash, you were out of luck. There are no, or very limited meats, and if there were, they cost 10 times their normal price. The schools could only open for half a day, and they were not serving lunch.”  I am so thankful for Juan’s willingness to serve Puerto Rico and the United States Coast Guard in this capacity and even more thankful to have him as a part of my staff. His feedback is an important reminder of how much work is still left to do for our friends and loved ones in Puerto Rico.

Such an honor to meet Pacita Agron and her family who are in town to receive the Congressional Gold Medal on behalf of her late husband, Alfred Agron. Alfred, the oldest living Alaska WWII veteran before he passed at the age of 104, served behind enemy lines in the Philippines during WWII, doing surveillance for the Army and fixing canons. What Agron did for our nation was extraordinary and significant. An incredible tribute.

Recently I joined my colleagues in the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs in an oversight hearing to advance bills aimed to improve public safety for Alaska Natives and American Indians. When one looks at the devastating statistics when it comes to murdered and missing Native women, the numbers are staggering and these horrific acts are far too prevalent. I do not believe here in this country that we bring nearly enough attention to the horrible issue. Many of the cases of domestic violence, rape, or violent crimes simply go unreported in Indian Country, and this is something that has to change. I believe bringing these bills to the table is a good start in addressing a variety of wrongs that exist in Indian Country and how the federal government can assist or flat-out do a better job. We need to give these issues the attention they deserve, we need coordination across federal agencies, and we need to ensure we have robust victim services to help victims get through the challenges they face.

I applaud President Trump for declaring the opioid crisis a public health emergency, today. Opioid addiction has become one of the most devastating public health issues confronting our nation. It is impacting everyone, destroying families, spurring crime, hurting our economy, and leading to the tragic deaths of far too many. The impacts of this epidemic are far reaching and fighting it will require all of us, including federal, state, tribal and local governments, as well as families, communities, and individuals to work together. Within my own state, Governor Walker declared the opioid epidemic a public health crisis in February, and has since worked to take practical steps to combat this crisis. Today’s declaration and the emphasis it brings is another important step which I hope will encourage more collaboration and coordination in our efforts. I remain dedicated to working alongside Alaskans in this fight against opioid addiction and substance abuse and will keep fighting for the resources we need.

Today I met with the Alaska Eskimo Whaling Commission (AEWC) about the cooperative management and harvest of bowhead whales. We also discussed the challenges facing Alaskans in the form of food security, cost of living, and bypass mail, among other things. AEWC is a shining example of a comanagement organization that works in tandem with the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) to manage bowhead whale subsistence hunting. Their mission is to safeguard the bowhead whale and its natural habitat and to help preserve the subsistence way of life that many Alaskan communities depend on. I’m so appreciative of all their hard work to ensure the traditions of our Alaska Natives are cherished and protected for generations to come.

I am horrified by the news of the attack in Manhattan yesterday. My heart goes out to those whose lives were taken, their families and their loved ones. They are in my prayers. This is a stark reminder that we must remain vigilant in the fight against terrorism.

Yesterday I chaired an Energy Committee oversight hearing where we heard from expert witnesses, including Fairbanks’ own Bruno Grunau from the Cold Climate Housing Research Center, on opportunities provided by advanced building management and control systems. While smart technologies have had a big impact on reducing energy use across the nation, in our own state, we’re still struggling to address high energy costs, so it’s encouraging to hear the significant strides being made to save on energy and create resilient, healthy, durable, sustainable homes in Alaska.

For over 40 years now, Alaskans have repeatedly proven that we can develop our energy resources safely and responsibly, and development in the 1002 Area will be no different.  This non-wilderness portion of ANWR was specifically designated for consideration for oil and gas exploration, and today the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources examined the potential of opening a very small portion of the 1002 Area for responsible development.  Alaskans understand that energy and the environment can coexist. We respect our land, and would never risk its future for the sake of development.  The economic benefits will be substantial, new jobs will be created, and our national security will be strengthened. Now is the time to open the 1002 Area, so we can realize those benefits.

Opening the 1002 Area to responsible oil and gas development will create thousands of new jobs, and those jobs will pay the types of wages that support families and put our kids through college. It will also generate tens of billions of dollars in revenues over the life of the fields for every level of government.

Many of the industries that allow our state to thrive involve some pretty dangerous work. The good news is, most recent studies show we’ve hit a record low for Alaska for workplace deaths. According to Alaska DOL/WD Commissioner Heidi Drygas, because of improvements in technology, increased training, and a stronger focus on safety- the rate has reduced by 85% since 1992. It is so encouraging to see this kind of progress when it comes to creating safe work environments for our friends and loved ones. I hope to continue striving to achieve the ultimate goal of zero fatalities.

Wonderful to celebrate with fellow Alaskans on the completion of GCI's TERRA project, a fiber optic network connecting 80 communities in western Alaska and providing them with high-speed broadband internet. Ted Stevens was among the first to secure federal funding for the TERRA network and since then, the Alaska delegation has worked diligently to ensure the continuation of this truly innovative project. The completion of this network is a launching pad for so many other potential advancements for our state. Whether it’s supporting telemedicine services to save lives, or distance education and internet-based learning that allows students of all ages to get the education they need while enabling them to stay in their communities- high-speed internet is so beneficial to our rural communities.

He has completed the qualifying round in Las Angeles, proving the importance of hard work and dedication to your craft. Tonight I released reconciliation legislation in accordance to the Senate Energy Committee’s instruction to raise $1 billion in federal revenues, which would open a small part of the non-wilderness portion of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (ANWR), known as the “1002 Area” or Coastal Plain, to responsible oil and gas development. The legislation will put Alaska and the entire nation on a path toward greater prosperity by creating jobs, keeping energy affordable for families and businesses, generating new wealth, and strengthening our security—while reducing the federal deficit.

It’s great to see the Administration working in conjunction with our Alaska leaders on this milestone for the Alaska LNG project. The responsible development of Alaska’s natural resources offers a great opportunity to create good jobs and new wealth in our state and across the country, while paying down both state and federal deficits, improving our balance of trade, and strengthening our national security. I stand ready to work with all stakeholders to advance the Alaska LNG project.

This Veterans Day, and every day, I am thankful for the men and women who have served in our military branches and have sacrificed so much for our nation’s freedom and protection. Veterans are our fathers, mothers, sons, and daughters. They are our co-workers, neighbors, community leaders, and our friends. We cannot thank them enough for being role models of courage, sacrifice, and service. We should remember to live every day appreciating the freedoms and liberties that our military has secured for all of us.  Today while we celebrate the service of all Veterans, we cannot forget those who have made the ultimate sacrifice and given everything to secure our country’s freedom. My heart is with their loved ones who feel their loss every day.   The members of our military and their families can never be honored enough, and deserve our unwavering support. Our veterans have done so much for each of us, so I hope each of us will take time to demonstrate our gratitude for our veterans and their families, by asking what we, as individuals and as a community, can do for them.

Today I had the chance to take part in a “We Honor Veterans” pinning ceremony in Anchorage, to acknowledge the military service and sacrifices made by these veterans and their families. It was an honor to take part in this special event and hear firsthand their personal stories.

On the eleventh hour, on the eleventh day of this eleventh month each year -- the point at which World War I ended -- communities across America are pausing to remember those who have defended our Nation’s freedom. Today we honor all those who have served, those currently serving, as well as mourn the veterans who made the ultimate sacrifice in the defense of freedom. I extend my heartfelt sympathy to the families of our fallen service members, as well to those throughout the rest of the country who have sacrificed so much so that we all can enjoy our freedoms. Words simply cannot express the gratitude that a grateful nation has for its veterans.

Today is Dr. Walter Soboleff day in Alaska. This day was established in hopes that Alaskans would remember the late Doctor’s teachings of respect, care, love, and compassion. This morning, I chaired an Energy and Natural Resources Committee Business Meeting to consider legislation to authorize responsible energy development in the 1002 Area of ANWR. I’m proud to share that we were successful in reporting it out of the Energy Committee.  Allowing responsible development will generate new wealth, reduce deficits, create good jobs, strengthen our national security, and help keep energy affordable for families. There is no question that development and environmental protection can and do exist in Alaska, because Alaskans have repeatedly proven that we can develop safely and responsibly. #EnergyIsGood

I am proud to join Senator Jeff Merkley to introduce the Supporting Working Moms Act, which ensures more working mothers can continue to nurse their babies when they return to work. This legislation encourages breastfeeding for working mothers, by making it more accessible for them to do so. We are helping to improve the health and well-being of both mother and child during one of the most critical stages of early development.

I, along with the rest of the Alaska Delegation, sent a letter to Secretary of State Rex Tillerson to address the downstream risks that mining in British Columbia may pose to Southeast Alaskan communities and habitats that surround transboundary rivers. We are stressing the need for communication between the U.S. and Canada on this issue, and want to ensure British Columbia institutes appropriate safeguards to prevent potential negative effects from the development of large-scale hard rock mine proposals and operations to transboundary waterways and fisheries. Mining, like fisheries, is an essential component of our state’s economy, but we must be assured that mineral development in B.C. does not disproportionally impact the ecosystems we depend on.

Every year on the 3rd Thursday of November, the American Cancer Society urges smokers throughout the country to take part in the Great American Smokeout, a day that encourages smokers to quit for 24 hours which will hopefully be the first step towards quitting for good. A worthy event and great opportunity to encourage folks to strive to begin a healthier, smoke-free lifestyle.

This week during a Military Construction, Veterans Affairs Appropriations Subcommittee Hearing, I questioned a panel of experts on the VA’s efforts to prevent and combat opioid overmedication and also the need for a more holistic system of care. Right now, our veterans have very limited options for pain management and treatment, so it is crucial that we are actively pursuing alternative methods, especially when they are in rural areas like Alaska and cannot physically reach a VA facility. We are making progress in lessening the overprescription of opioids, but it is so important that we are working with the VA and urging them to create new plans for pain management to avoid disruptive gaps in the treatment and healing of our veterans.

While we work towards the day where no one chooses to end their life, we must also remember those left behind by the tragedy of suicide. My prayer is that these gatherings help provide needed comfort and healing. #survivorday

I am proud to cosponsor a bipartisan bill that will enforce our federal criminal history reporting procedures to help keep weapons away from criminals. The Fix NICS Act requires federal and state authorities to accurately report relevant criminal history records, ensuring the National Instant Criminal Background Check (NICS) System contains accurate and up-to-state information on individuals that may be prohibited from purchasing a firearm. While there is significant disagreement over the role that the government should play in regulating firearms, we can all agree that we must do everything we can to keep Americans safe and to keep guns out of the hands of abusers and criminals. Thanks to Senator Cornyn for his leadership in introducing this bill to keep firearms from falling into dangerous hands while still respecting Americans’ constitutional right to bear arms.

I was glad to join my colleagues on the Senate HELP Committee this morning as we began to lay the groundwork for changing federal laws to improve college access, affordability, enrollment, and completion. Today’s hearing was a useful, detailed discussion about how to simplify the FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) to make it a help for students and families rather than a barrier to post-secondary education. I look forward to additional conversations in committee to address issues I hear about from so many Alaskans, such as the cost of college, the complexity of federal student aid, and the burden of college loan debt.

Happy to report the FDA officially changed the acceptable market name of Brown King Crab to Golden King Crab, as it is commonly called throughout Alaska. I worked to secure language that amended the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to update the FDA’s seafood list to assist with Golden King Crab marketing. Alaskans have been fighting for this name change for years. I’m glad to finally update the name and to be a part of supporting the needs of our state’s world class fishing industry.

Today in a HELP committee hearing, I had the opportunity to hear from the nominee for Health and Human Services Secretary, Mr. Alex Azar. As the former Deputy Secretary of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Mr. Azar has had the opportunity to spend time in Alaska getting to know some of our communities and the specific challenges we face. One area of focus I asked Mr. Azar to expand on, was his view on the role of patient navigators within our state and how he would ensure our rural areas remain connected and supported in understanding their healthcare options.

After thoroughly reviewing the good work of the Finance Committee, I intend to support the reconciliation legislation that is now before the Senate.   Because the bill includes provisions originating in the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, Alaskans can expect to see me co-managing it with my colleagues, Budget Chairman Mike Enzi and Finance Chairman Orrin Hatch.   The bill before us has a number of features that are very attractive to Alaskans. It lowers tax rates, doubles the child tax credit, and provides tax relief for many families by doubling the standard deduction. It promotes economic growth, employment, and investment by improving the tax code for corporations and small businesses. And it removes the tax penalty for those who do not wish to purchase health insurance that they cannot afford or that offers little value to them.   Of course, the bill also includes a title that I am proud to have written, to open a small portion of the non-wilderness 1002 Area in ANWR in northeast Alaska to responsible energy production.   We still have work to do on this legislation and I look forward to the debate on the Senate floor and my colleagues’ ideas to further improve it.   Outside of the tax legislation, we must enact healthcare reforms to help stabilize the individual market. The Alexander-Murray bill helps to accomplish that, and as an original cosponsor of that effort, I will continue to encourage the President and my colleagues to act swiftly on it.

I am excited that negotiations have concluded on the Agreement to Prevent Unregulated High Seas Fisheries in the Central Arctic Ocean, which will help to end unregulated commercial fishing, establish oceanic research programs and develop a Regional Fishery Management Organization ---all in the high seas portion of the central Arctic Ocean. This multi-national agreement ushers in a new era for international cooperation in the Arctic and ensures that Alaska’s Indigenous peoples will be active participants in decisions affecting the resources off our shores. Senator Ted Stevens and I set this work in motion many years ago, so I am especially glad to see it come to fruition. A great step towards developing sustainable fisheries and a compliment to the legacy Senator Stevens left behind.

This decision by the EPA will protect the jobs of miners throughout Alaska and the rest of the country, protect our nation’s mineral security, and make sure that we can responsibly access resources needed for our national defense, manufacturing and other high-tech industries.

During my tenure as a US Senator, I have been a steadfast advocate for the Secure Rural Schools (SRS) program. This program has been a critical lifeline for rural Alaska communities by providing much needed funding for essential public services, including schools, road maintenance, and search and rescue operations, as timber receipts decline. Until the federal government allows increased timber harvesting in our federal forests, we must reauthorize the SRS program to ensure that our rural communities relying on this program are provided for. I have sent a letter to our Senate leaders to support local rural communities by reauthorizing this important program.

I also highlighted the bipartisan legislation, the Energy and Natural Resources Act, that I reintroduced this year with Ranking Member Senator Maria Cantwell to reform the permitting process. Whether it is energy production, pipelines, pumped storage, water supply, mining, or LNG, the permitting system needs to be improved across the board, and our bill will help us make needed progress. Today we unveiled the final conference committee report for H.R. 1, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. I’m grateful to my fellow conferees for working incredibly hard to reconcile our differences on tax reform and reach an agreement that reduces rates, lets hard-working Americans keep more of their own money, and makes our nation’s businesses more competitive. I am proud to have recently introduced the Coastal Communities Ocean Acidification Act, a bipartisan bill to identify and assess communities, including island communities, low-population rural communities, and subsistence communities, that are most dependent on coastal and ocean resources that may be impacted by ocean acidification. Alaska’s culture and economy thrive on so many resources that come from the ocean. This proactively addresses a very real issue and will help us all gain a deeper understanding of how ocean acidification is affecting our coastal and subsistence communities throughout Alaska. This is significant legislation for those living in a state or community whose livelihood greatly depends on the health of our oceans.

It’s been a busy December, working on overhauling our nation’s outdated tax code and moving one step closer to achieving the decades long goal of opening a small portion of the 1002 Area, within the non-wilderness portion of ANWR, to responsible resource development. Here’s a quick update with what’s been happening here in D.C. and how it may impact you.

Prior to the Senate taking up a vote, I spoke on the floor in support of the tax reform package. I’m excited to join so many of my colleagues in strong support of this conference report. It’s time to reform the tax code, for the good of our country.  And it’s time to open the non-wilderness 1002 Area to responsible development, for the benefit of all Alaskans and Americans.

The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act has passed the House and the Senate and is now headed to the President to be signed into law. The passage of this bill marks a defining moment in our nation’s history. In addition to reforming the tax code, Title II of the bill, which I authored, opens the non-wilderness 1002 Area of ANWR to responsible energy development. We have fought to open the 1002 Area for a very long time, and now, our day has finally arrived. I thank all who kept this effort alive over the decades and for the efforts of my colleagues,  Congressman Young and Senator Sullivan. This is a major victory for Alaska that will help us fulfill the promises of our statehood and give us renewed hope for growth and prosperity.
